title: alex-salmond-returns-politics-leader-new-alba-party
story: Scotlandrsquos former first minister Alex Salmond is seeking to make a dramaticto Holyrood, as the leader of the new pro-independence Alba Party.Mr Salmond confirmed he will be standing for the party on the North East regional list section in Mayrsquos Scottish Parliament election.Launching the new party in an online event, the former SNP leader said: ldquoToday Alba are hoisting a flag in the wind, planting our Saltire on a hill. In the next few weeks we will see how many will rally to our standard.The launch of his party comes after a turbulent period for the SNP and the Scottish Government, led by Mr Salmondrsquos successor Nicola Sturgeon.He accused senior figures within the SNP of mounting a conspiracy against him, after he successfully challenged the way the Government handled harassment claims made against him by two women.A Holyrood inquiry into the Governmentrsquos botched handling of those complaints was critical of both Ms Sturgeon and her administration, as it concluded the two complainers were ldquobadly let down.Mr Salmond was last year cleared after a criminal trial of a series of allegations, including a charge of attempted rape.He insisted on Friday that after the series of court cases and inquiries, it is now ldquotime to move on.ldquoI have wanted to talk about the future of Scotland for the last three years. Now I have got the opportunity thanks to the Alba Party, he said.ldquoThatrsquos what I intend to do, and I intend to do it in an entirely positive way.He said the party has been set up to win seats using Holyroodrsquos regional lists.vw,vw,px, px"Alex Salmond was cleared of a series of sexual assault charges after a trial at the High Court in Edinburgh last year The proportional representation system at Holyrood sees MSPs elected from constituencies, with additional members elected from eight regional lists in a bid to ensure each partyrsquos total number of MSPs is in proportion to the percentage of votes it receives.While the SNP has been successful in winning constituency seats, Mr Salmond said his former party could end up with no MSPs at all from the regional section of the ballot.The latestopinion polls suggest the SNP on the lists ldquowould win no seats whatsoever, despite having the best part of a million votes, he said.This would mean these votes are ldquototally wasted, he said.Mr Salmond continued: ldquoThe Alba Party is a list party, we are standing only on the list, wersquore not challenging the SNP in the constituency.ldquoIndeed we are saying vote SNP or for an independence party on the constituency section, we are giving that support.He said his new party will help ldquoreinforce the momentum behind the independence cause.The Alba Party has said it will field at least four candidates in each of the regional lists.Alex Salmond Statement https:t.co wIATOmfuvmdash Alba PartyMarch , Chris McEleny, who was voted in as anSNP councillor in Inverclyde, has resigned from Ms Sturgeonrsquos party to stand in theWest of Scotland for the Alba Party.Mr Salmond said: ldquoOver the next six weeks we will promote new ideas about taking Scotland forward, giving primacyto economic recovery from the pandemic and the achievement of independence for our country.ldquoWe expect to field a minimum of four candidates in each regional list and wersquore hoping to elect Alba MSPs from every area of Scotland.Mr Salmond said the aim of the party is to work towards a ldquosuccessful, socially just, environmentally responsible, independent country.The launch of the party comes days after Mr Salmond announced plans to take legal action over the ldquoconduct of the Scottish Governmentrsquos top civil servant Leslie Evans.He said the Permanent Secretary failed to take ldquoreal responsibility for failings highlighted in two reports this week about the Governmentrsquos investigation of harassment complaints against him..push,i[r].l*new title: commission-clears-france-complicity-rwanda-genocide
story: A commission that spent nearly two years uncovering Francersquos role in rsquos Rwandan genocide concluded that the country reacted too slowly in appreciating the extent of the horror that left over , dead but cleared it of complicity in the slaughter.The report said that France bears ldquoheavy and overwhelming responsibilities in the drt that led to the killings, which principally claimed victims from Rwandarsquos Tutsi ethnic minority.Persistent claims that France under then-president Francois Mitterrand did not do enough to stop the genocide have damaged the Franco-Rwandan relationship since the s.As a result, French President Emmanuel Macron ordered the -member commission in May  to shed light on what happened in Rwanda between  and .Officials in Mr Macronrsquos office said the inquiry was not just about improving relations with Rwanda but with the whole African continent, since other countries also have questions about what France did at the time.The commissionrsquos report apportioned blame to France for failing in its ldquopolitical, institutional, intellectual, ethicalmoral responsibility, according to officials in Mr Macronrsquos office." title: young-children-find-creative-ways-support-leuchie-house-home
story: All were raising money for Leuchie House respite centre, found on the outskirts of North Berwick.Harris Gordon attended the North Berwick school hub, where he planned and designed a shop which he then built with his family as a home school project using spare decking.The seven-year-old, who is in primary three, set up his stall at the end of his drive in Cala Homesrsquo Law Garden development and charmed passers-by into buying his produce, which consisted of sweets, crisps and eggs.As well as hand sanitiser, he had bags for people to put their items into.Dad Jonathan said: ldquoHarris was always talking about a shop and making money and buying items from the wholesalers and selling them, so we saidhe wanted to do it, it would be best to do it for charity.ldquoThrough the project he learned all about pricing, working out profit, writing the labels and marketing.ldquoOur neighbours were really generous in supporting Harrisrsquos project and of course Leuchie House we got more than we thought we would get and raised about pound.Harris has plans to continue his social enterprise with ideas for home baking and home-grown seedlings.In Prestonpans, Caleb, aged eight, and Esther Shearer, aged four, set up lsquoThe Litter Picking Squadrsquo after Caleb was inspired having seen a similar story on the CBBC show Newsround, subsequently asking for a litter picker for Christmas.Caleb and Esther are raising money for Leuchie House by picking litterCaleb is in primary four at Preston Tower Primary School and Esther is in her pre-school nursery year at Preston Tower Nursery.The brother-and-sister duo said: ldquoWe were so sad seeing all the litter out on our daily walks that we decided to do something about it and raise money for some great charities at the same time.They initially aimed to raise pound for collecting  bags of litter.But after being supported by family and friends, the target was soon upped to pound ndash they finished their challenge with a total of pound.Caleb and Esther are encouraging other children to join lsquoThe Litter Picking Squadrsquo and collect rubbish in their local area while raising money at the same time and becoming more aware of their surroundings.To donate, visit justgiving fundraising thelitterpickingsquadleuchiehouse or for more information on lsquoThe Litter Picking Squadrsquo visit facebook thelitterpickingsquadAfter the  bags, they will choose another charity to fundraise for, hoping they can continue their efforts for as long as possible.Mum Sarah added: ldquoSadly, we do see a lot of folk just chucking rubbish straight to the street, even when a bin is only a few feet away.ldquoWe know that there are loads of beach cleans that are organised just now. Such efforts are truly amazing. We just figured we might as well raise funds for much-loved charities at the same time as we pick up litter.ldquoIt gives Caleb and Esther huge motivation to know they are doing it for a good cause.Mark Bevan, CEO of Leuchie House, said: ldquoHome schooling and working from home is tough.ldquoItrsquos great to see these imaginative young entrepreneurs learning lots of le skills about the environment and commerce and doing good at the same time, a lesson many business leaders could learn from!

title: family-reunited-lost-wedding-pictures-1957
story: Wendy Carroll, of Port Seton, posted the photographs on social media after her husband Brian came across an album while working in the attic of their daughter Chloersquos home on Musselburghrsquos Delta Road, which she moved to one-and-a-half years ago.Wendy said: ldquoI love old photos so he brought it home for me to look at.ldquoWhen I saw them, they were gorgeous and just full of memories.She decided to track down the family but, due to the Covid- pandemic, her search was put on hold until recently, when the photos were uploaded to social media.Wendy said the response was ldquoamazing and, within half an hour, someone recognised the wedding party.The photos were of the marriage of Musselburgh woman Una McCann and Tommy Brodie , from Armadale, on June , , at Our Lady of Loretto and St Michael Church, Musselburgh.Tommy was in the RAF, stationed in Ayr, and Una and her friend went on holiday to Ayr, where she met him at the Bobby Jones dance hall.Their only child, Monica Warnock , a Wallyford resident, collected the album from Wendy the next day.Wendy said: ldquoI was so happy toit to where it belonged.Mum-of-three Monica, who has four grandchildren, was delighted to have the album back, saying her parents orced and both remarried.She said that her half-brother Russell Brodie, who lives with his we Jenni in Edinburgh, had never seen a photograph of his grandmother, who was in the wedding photo, standing at the groomrsquos side.Monica said: ldquoMy mother gave me the album  years ago. My daughter Michaela Malone had the album in her house and it somehow ended up in the attic.ldquoShe moved from Delta Road to Ormiston about three years ago and it was left in the attic by mistake.ldquoNo one realised it was missing. Wendyrsquos husband was doing work in the attic when he found it.She added that, when the photos went on Facebook, her cousins alerted her.Una , a great-grandmother-of-five, now , lives in Edinburghrsquos Craigentinny with her husband Jack. Tommy passed away in .Monica said: ldquoI took the album to my mum and she enjoyed looking at the old photographs of her family. I will keep it safe for the family to keep through the generations.

title: plot-land-blindwells-goes-sale-housebuilders
story: Marketing has commenced on the .-hectare site, which is called lsquoplot rsquo and is positioned in the northwest corner of the former opencast mine site.Planning permission in principle is already in place for the first phase of the Blindwells development, between Tranent and Cockenzie and Port Seton.Plot  has the capacity to accommodate about  new homes and site owner Hargreaves Land believes it will appeal to housebuilders looking to get a foothold in the new town.Iain Slater, development and estates director at Hargreaves Land, said: ldquoDespite Covid-,  has started on a very positive note for Blindwells.ldquoWe are making excellent progress thanks to our investment in remediation and infrastructure works, but also as a result of the strong underlying demand for good-quality new homes in popular locations.Property consultancy JLL, which is appointed as sole agent for Hargreaves Land, anticipates strong interest and will be seeking offers in late April.The latest announcement follows on the heels of Bellway commencing groundworks on its forthcoming -unit Princersquos Gate development on the Blindwells site.Similarly, in recent weeks Hargreaves Land has also exchanged a conditional sale contract with Persimmon for a .-acre plot where there is capacity for a further  homes, including  designated as affordable.Jason Hogg, director at JLL, said: ldquoHouse prices, sales and demand in East Lothian have surged in the last  months as home buyers seek accommodation that embraces additional space, technology and a high amenity environment ndash Blindwells can capitalise on this and we look forward to discussing the opportunity with the wider market.

title: musselburgh-sea-cadets-virtual-walk-london-back
story: Along with family members, they are logging their steps or kilometres, completed daily during March, via an online tracker which calculates the distance walked for each day.They had originally planned to walk km, from Musselburgh to London, but smashed their target distance and started thejourney back to the Honest Toun ndash a total of ,km.They have already raised nearly pound,.Chief Officer Mark Tfin , from Gorebridge, is supporting the unit ndash TS Indefatigable ndash by taking part in the virtual sponsored walk while on his Maersk Line Hamburg Sud ship off Chinarsquos coast, covering more than km.Funds raised will be used to provide training when the cadetsto their newly refurbished unit building on South Street after Covid- restrictions are eased.The property has undergone a full upgrade costing pound, to include new toilet and shower facilities, offices and classroom space. Improved teaching equipment such as interactive teaching boards have also been installed.Funding of pound, was received from the Marine Society and Sea Cadets, pound, from Viridor, pound, from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund and pound, from fundraising and donations.Petty Officer Belle Milliken said: ldquoDue to the current pandemic, the unit has lost out on a lot of our usual fundraising route and, with the team taking part in the sponsored walk, it will enable them to get out, get fit, improve wellbeing and spend time with family as part of their team.She said: ldquoThe money will support ourto parading, purchasing training equipment for the cadets in face-to-face classes, and upkeep for the current equipment and boats.The group provides --year-olds with a range of opportunities, from first aid to boating qualications, all based around the Royal Navy.PO Milliken said the cadets were looking forward to ing to normal activities after the Covid- crisis.She said: ldquoWe were hoping tolate last year but, due to awaiting final certication for the building work, this was put on hold.ldquoAt the moment we are parading as normal but on Zoom and delivering specialisation training in communication systems, promotion training, first aid, engineering, Duke of Edinburgh, boating theory, catering, BTEC and CVQO.ldquoWe have also had sessions delivered by the Royal Navy engagement team on careers and flags at sea, which is a Royal Navy communication session.One cadet said: ldquoPersonally, joining sea cadets was one of the best things I have done.ldquoIt has provided me with a confidence and experiences that just simply cannot be learnt within a classroom.ldquoIt has given me an insight into Royal Navy le and has helped me meet many friends from all across the UK who will be friends for le.Anyone wishing to donate to the sponsored walk can go to gofundme f musselburgh-sea-cadets-sponsored-virtual-walk-

title: teenager-launches-petition-bins-wallyford
story: While out walking his Jack Russell terrier Madi, Corgan James-Robertson, , noticed a shortage of bins around the village after moving there with his family in March last year.He is concerned about the amount of dog dirt and poo bags left lying around, as well as rubbish including plastic items such as bottles.He hopes the petition, which currently has more than  signatures, will encourage the council to provide more bins in the area.Corgan, a pupil at Portobello High School, said that there were recycling bins everywhere in Portobello, where he used to live, so it was easy to dispose of drink bottles and cans.He said: ldquoIn Wallyford there are none and only one rubbish bin ndash not even the bus stops have bins near them.He added: ldquoEver since I moved to Wallyford in March , I have noticed that there is a shortage of bins around Wallyford.ldquoThere is a lot of dog faeces, plastics rubbish and dog poo bags left lying around.ldquoI would like to get the attention of East Lothian Council to get more bins that would include recycling and rubbish.Even Madi is helping with the initiative, as the environmentally conscious canine always recycles a discarded bottle while out for a walk by bringing one home each time .Corganrsquos mum Samantha said: ldquoWe just noticed that there were so many lying everywhere.Corgan decided to take action and has sent his petition to local MSP Colin Beattie, and plans to write to East Lothian Council at the end of his campaign.The family are ldquofirm believers in recycling and the effects of discarded plastic bottles and bags on the environment.The petition is available to view online at change.org p east-lothian-council-to-get-more-bins-in-wallyford

title: pupils-get-insight-world-finance-apprentice-scheme
story: Pupils from Dunbar Grammar School, North Berwick High School and Preston Lodge High School have spent lockdown preparing for the world of work by undertaking foundation apprenticeships in providing financial services with Social Investment Scotland .Rachel Miller, who attends Preston Lodge Dunbar Grammar pupil Abbie Chisholm and Emma Roy, of North Berwick High, have been working towards the qualication for the last  months alongside their regular schoolwork.They have had to balance the demands of the apprenticeship programme with online learning during the pandemic.Foundation apprenticeships were launched in  to help S and S pupils gain work experience while still at school, with the qualication equivalent to an SQA Higher.They are offered to senior school pupils as part of the curriculum when making their subject choices.The pupils have already achieved a National Progression Award after completing the classroom-style learning segment of the course, which was delivered by Limelight Careers on behalf of East Lothian Council.A large part of the programme usually involves a work-based placement however, given the work-from-home guidance, many of the placements with financial services providers have been put on hold.SIS stepped in to offer the pupils an opportunity to join the team virtually.Emma, , enjoyed the experience. She said: ldquoOver the last year, regular schoolwork and exams have been so up in the air, but itrsquos been reassuring to have the apprenticeship programme going on at the same time, which will give me a formal qualication.ldquoIrsquove developed my knowledge of finance throughout the programme but have also had the opportunity to build confidence and practice other skills like teamwork and communication.SIS was one of the first financial organisations in Scotland to support this kind of foundation apprenticeship for school pupils.In the last two years, the organisation has welcomed six pupils to its team as part of their learning experience, supporting them on their journey into employment.Lindsay Wake, head of impact at SIS, said: ldquoWersquove been impressed with the pupilsrsquo resilience and willingness to learn, despite the uncertainty of the world around them, and we hope to see them continue on to exciting and rewarding careers in the financial services sector.

title: merryhatton-column-great-plants-getting-children-gardening
story: This month, wersquore taking a look at some plants that theyrsquoll find easy to grow, starting from seed.If this is a childrsquos first experience of gardening, you might want to consider seeds that will germinate easily and quickly.For example, microgreens can be grown indoors, germinating and ready to eat within only days from sowing.Salad leaves such as lettuce can be sown indoors at this time of year and finished outdoors once the weather is warmer. After the frosts are gone, they can be grown from seed outdoors, either in pots or beds.Since lettuce can be ready to eat within as little as six weeks from sowing, itrsquos a good idea to sow a few seeds every week or two to ensure a continuous supply of salad throughout summer.For more experienced young gardeners, round carrots are a relatively quick crop that grow well in pots. Varieties like lsquoParis Marketrsquo produce tasty snacks that can be harvested - weeks from sowing.A slightly longer crop but nevertheless very popular is the pumpkin ndash sow the seeds now and theyrsquoll be a fine size for carving lanterns and making pumpkin pie in the autumn. Once they begin to fill out, they are fascinating to watch as they grow almost visibly from day to day!The choice of flower seeds is too extensive to list here, so wersquove highlighted three of the easiest and most rewarding to consider.Nasturtiums are possibly the most popular amongst flower seeds for young gardeners. These large seeds are easy for children to handle, can be germinated indoors during early spring and planted outdoors in pots or borders when the risk of frost is gone.Flowering from June right through to October, the flowers and leaves can be used in salads. By removing dead heads, repeat flowering is encouraged. They produce seed very easily and itrsquos entirely possible that you might find nasturtiums unexpectedly popping up again next year!The ever-popular poppy is another favourite and our recommendation here are the lsquoLittle Ladybirdrsquo poppies ndash with their black-spotted centres on bright red flowers, you can almost imagine that they are a family of ladybirds!When thinking about flowers that can be easily grown from seed, itrsquos impossible to ignore sweet peas.Try creating your very own sweet pea tepee with a few bamboos and some twine. Plant the sweet peas around the base of the tepee , then train the plants up and around as they grow to create a tent with living walls. With endless fragrant flowers and a tepee to play in, itrsquos sure to be a winner for all the family!For many of todayrsquos gardeners, their own plot in the garden is where their love of gardening first began.Whilst not every garden has the space to have a dedicated kids area, therersquos often room to let children grow things in containers.Why not set them the challenge of finding the most unusual colourful imaginative container and see what they come up with  Old toys, kitchen containers or even old shoes and boots can be fun containers to grow plants in and could be decorated to produce wonderfully inidual planters. Just make sure that theyrsquore clean before you begin, that they have sufficient drainage so that the plants donrsquot become waterlogged and that they will remain intact when watered.If you donrsquot have a garden, perhaps you could let them experiment with houseplants or a window box With so much evidence about the benefits to our wellbeing of gardening, introducing children to this wonderful pastime is certainly worth considering. You may be launching a future horticulturalist or simply helping them learn how gardening can help them remain healthy and well but itrsquos certainly worth having a go!Although we are currently closed due to Government guidance, our plant team are here in the garden centre caring for the plants and can be contacted by email at info@merryhatton or telephonefor help and advice. Yoursquoll also find lots of information and can purchase your seeds on our website at www.merryhatton

title: puppet-animation-festival-returning-east-lothian-easter
story: This year it moves online due to the Covid- pandemic, replacing the performances and workshops for primary school children which usually take place in venues throughout the country.Organised by The Brunton in Musselburgh and East Lothian Councilrsquos arts service, the festival will feature two performances to watch through the theatrersquos website and two fun workshops to take part in via Zoom.The Incredible Tale of Robot Boy, by Theatre Rites, one of the UKrsquos leading theatre companies, will be shown on Saturday, April , at .am and pm for ages eight plus.In the most extraordinary high-tech laboratory, a team of the worldrsquos top scientists are attempting the impossible ndash to create a robot with a real brain. Their aim is to push the boundaries of scientic discovery. They succeed and Robot Boy is born.It is described as ldquoa poetic story about humanity, responsibility and le, with dazzling puppetry, interactive film and performance.The Selfish Giant, by Tessa Bide Productions, Bristolrsquos leading family theatre experts, is on Saturday, April , at .am and pm for ages three plus.Inspired by the touching childrenrsquos story The Selfish Giant by Oscar Wilde, it uses powerful storytelling, captivating puppetry, beautul design, enchanting music and a sprinkling of audience interaction to explore an unusual friendship and how even the grumpiest giantrsquos heart can melt when spring finally arrives.Tickets for the two shows are pound each . This is per viewing ndash regardless of the number of people watching together at the same time.Two fun and interactive workshops presented by Temporary Commons offer the chance to stay connected and get creative. Bookers will receive a pack with all the materials needed, as well as a Zoom link to join the workshop online, led by professional puppet creators.Sing Song Bird Puppet workshop is on Saturday, April , at am and pm, for ages eight plus.Using collage and pop-up card-folding techniques, participants will make a bird puppet with a moving beak. These birds love to sing, squawk and chatter. The birds sing a simple song which will be shared at the end of the workshop.The Wibble Wobble Clown workshop is on Saturday, April , at am and .pm, for ages five plus.These puppets are collages made from simple shapes, then assembled with split pins. Once theyrsquore made, the clowns will parade, to test their tipple topple, wibble wobble.Each workshop costs pound per participant, which includes postage of all the materials needed, as well as access to the professional-led online workshops.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoThe Brunton has worked hard throughout the pandemic to find and provide the best possible performancesand workshops for our audiences. We hope our work with the festival will bring enjoyment and pleasure at this challenging time for us all.A spokesperson for Puppet Animation Festival said: ldquoThis year has been incredibly challenging for both young people and their parents across the country, with issues of isolation, lack of social contact, exhaustion and diminished support networks affecting most families in the UK.ldquoItrsquos therefore more important than ever to find moments of playfulness, escape and creativity, which is why Puppet Animation Festival will offer the chance for families to watch high-quality work and to get creative themselves.Puppet festival events can be booked with The Brunton by phone on    or online at www.thebrunton

title: plans-adopt-pencaitland-phonebox-keep-swap-shop
story: Calls from the phonebox, at the junction of the villagersquos Main Street and Lempockwells Road, have dwindled over the years due to the increased use of mobile phones.At the same time, it has become ldquoan informal swap shop for CDs, magazines, books and DVDs, with the community now set to adopt the iconic structure.Ralph Averbuch, chairman of the villagersquos community council, said an agreement had been submitted to BT to formally take over the phonebox.He said: ldquoI donrsquot think a great deal may be done ndash some love and care in terms of a lick of paint, decent shelving to properly display the CDs, books and DVDs and other stuff in there.A number of East Lothian phoneboxes were removed last year, with the dwindling use highlighted by BT. The Pencaitland phonebox escaped the chopping block at the time.Mr Averbuch added: ldquoJust after that exercise was completed, we had a member of the Farsquoside Area Partnershipteam knock on my door saying BT had been complaining about all the magazines and books and wanted them cleared out.ldquoWe had been running this informal swap shop for years and years and years.ldquoWe know perfectly well that hardly anybody uses a phonebox ndash the data that has been gathered about how much it is used backs that up.Now, a decision has been made to attempt to formally adopt the phonebox, with BT expected to remove the telecommunications equipment within a matter of weeks.From there, the plan is to continue running a swap shop.Cabinet maker Adrian Hickey has offered to create some shelves to ensure the space is used efficiently.Adopted phoneboxes throughout the country have found a iety of dferent uses, from floral planters and miniature libraries to tiny art museums and the ldquoworldrsquos smallest nightclub.

title: covid-minutes-silence-candle-vigil----time-people
story: Prominent buildings and landmarks throughout the UK will be illuminated as part of the national day of reflection, including the Kelpies, Wallace Monument and Ness Bridge.End of le charity Marie Curie is organising the event, which is being backed by more than  organisations, including the emergency services, businesses, charities and community groups.The Scottish Government is among those supporting the event and is inviting people to take part and to reach out to someone they know is grieving.Ken Macintosh, the Scottish Parliamentrsquos presiding officer, will lead the minutersquos silence on the garden lobby steps at Holyrood at  noon along with party leaders.Also, many people have lost loved ones to causes other than Covid over the past  months. The restrictions in place have made the grieving process even more dficult than it would have been - my thoughts are with you too.People are later being encouraged to stand on their doorsteps at pm with phones, candles and torches to signy a ldquobeacon of remembrance.The latest National Records of Scotland figures indicate , deaths were registered in Scotland where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate, as of March .First Minister Nicola Sturgeon previously said it is ldquoright we pause to remember those we have lost, and offer our continued thoughts, solidarity and support to the bereaved.She added: ldquoAs we remember, we can also reflect on how far we have come in a relatively short period of time, and begin to look toward the future.ldquoBecause of our collective sacrice, there are people alive now who would otherwise have lost their le to the virus and we now have vaccines, offering us hope that we can soon get back to a more normal way of le.ldquoBy supporting one another and sticking with restrictions a little longer, we will get out of this crisis andto a world where we can properly see friends and loved ones again, travel freely, and work, socialise and go on holiday once more.

title: popular-baby-boy-girl-names-2020-scotland-revealed
story: Jack remains the most popular boys name, holding on to the top spot for the th consecutive year.Noah is now the second most popular boys name, having jumped from th place last year, and meanwhile James stays in rd place.Isla overtakes Olivia as the top name for baby girls for the first time, with Olivia taking the second spot and Emily now being the third most popular name, according to the full lists of  baby names published by National Records of Scotlandtoday.The girls name Maeve made a massive leap of  places from last year, up to th place, and Ayda, the second highest climber in the girls top  list, rose  places to the st spot.The biggest increases in the top  boys list were Roman, which jumped up  places to rd, and Finley, which rose  places to th.Of the , girls registered in Scotland last year, there were , dferent names, whilst more boys shared the same name. Of the , boys registered, there were only , dferent names. Children nowadays are much less likely to share a name with classmates than their grandparents were.Julie Ramsay, Vital Events Statistician, said:ldquoWe can see from the  names lists that dferent generations of parents have dferent preferences for naming their babies."Isla, the most popular name for girls in , was the most popular name with mothers aged  and over, but it only ranked th with mothers aged under ."However, Olivia, the most popular girls name of , was ranked st by younger mothers and th by older mothers."She added: "Jack, the most popular name for boys in , was the nd most popular name with mothers aged  and above, and only th with mothers aged under ."James was the most popular name for boys with older mothers while Noah was ranked st for younger mothers."Popular culture often affects how people name their babies. The name Billie rose in popularity by % in the past two years with  baby girls being given this name in ."In the same time, Google searches in the UK forldquoBillie and ldquoBillie Eilish spiked, with the singer having her first number one single in the UK in early ."Tommy, a name occurring in the popular TV shows Peaky Blinders and Love Island, has doubled in popularity in the last two years, with  boys being given this name."Our data shows it is more popular with younger mothers than with older mothers."View the full list here.

title: seven-year-old-girl-abandoned-tears-mile-home-bus-driver
story: The primary three pupil at Yester Primary School is said to live between Gford and Garvald and was on the school bus home last Friday afternoon, a service run by Prentice Buses.According to eyewitnesses, the bus driver did not stop at her address she is then said to have told the driver that he missed her stop, a statement he is said to have ignored.Older pupils on the bus are then said to have also pleaded with the driver to turn the bus around and drop the child off at her home, which he allegedly also ignored.The driver is then said to have continued on the route to Garvald, where he dropped off some pupils as well as the child affected. Garvald is about two miles from her home.Eyewitnesses say that the child was left ldquodistraught, ldquocrying and very scared and despite the children shouting at the driver, they say he drove away and ldquoabandoned her in Garvald, with no way home and walking the only alternative.Another parent is said to have taken her home.Prentice Busesrsquo managing director has said that the driver was unaware the child was wanting to get off at the stop but steps were being taken to ensure such an incident didnrsquot happen again.The childrsquos grandmother, Susan Smeaton, called the incident ldquonegligence as ldquodrivers have a duty of care to make sure the kids are safely dropped off at their homes.She added: ldquoThere are no pavements on the rural area, anything could have happened to her.ldquoIf it had been last week with just the primary one to primary threes at school, she would have been in that village on her own. This is not acceptable.A complaint has been lodged by the childrsquos family to East Lothian Council following the incident and investigations are continuing.Ross Prentice, managing director of Prentice Buses, said that the route was one the company had been running for nearly  years.He said that to his knowledge and from speaking to his driver, no one shouted back at them and no one said anything to them.He said that the driver shouted back to aska child was getting off at the stop but, as he did not hear any response and there was no parent waiting ndash something the family denies ndash they continued on to the next stop, where several children got off.On turning round and passing through Garvald again, they saw no children waiting.Mr Prentice said that it was not unusual for children to get off at dferent stops, for examplethey were going to visit a friend.He added thatthe driver saw the child crying he would have gone back and dropped her off at her home rather than leaving her behind.Mr Prentice said: ldquoSafety is very important to us, we do not take it lightly and want to make sure that this does not happen again.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe received a complaint from the family about this incident and officers are investigating the issues raised with the contractor concerned.ldquoWe take seriously our responsibilities to all the children and young people who use our home to school transport.ldquoAs this is the subject of ongoing discussions as part of our formal complaints process, it would be inappropriate for us to comment further.

title: areas-scotland-underwater-2050
story: Glasgow Airport, the Old Course at St Andrews and the Kelpies in Falkirk are among the key sites that could be flooded,research by Climate Central is correct.The organisation is made up of leading scientists and journalists who research climate change and its impact on the public.It has created an interactive map, using current projections to show which areas of the country could be lost to rising sea levels by .Here, we look at what areas in Scotland could be lost according to the study.The centre of Edinburgh remains fairly unscathed in the predictions, with Leith taking the brunt of the hit, according to the study.Picture: Climate CentralThe usually busy Portbello beach will likely look completely changedthe study fairs true, meanwhile further south Musselburgh faces having a vast chunk of its land removed.There, the racecourse and golf courses look set to be underwater.Picture: Climate CentralNorth Berwick, Belhaven, Dunbar and Torness Nuclear Power Station all look at risk.Across the Borders, coastal towns like St Abbs and Eyemouth face a treacherous future, according to the study, with Eyemouth harbour and beach facing being overrun with water.All areas inland face an easier time of it.Picture: Climate CentralOver on the East coast, areas like Annan, Gretna, Stranraer and Cairnryan will also have a completely dferent coastline.The study predicts a widening of the River Clyde, with itrsquos riverbank completely changing.Glasgow Airport would be submerged under the rising water, with Braehead Shopping Centre and the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital also at risk.The SEC and Science Centre would also be entirely consumed by the water.Moving west, the structural integrity of the Erskine Bridge would be brought into question, meanwhile the Titan Crane and West College Scotland campus in Clydebank could be lost.The study suggests that nearly the entirety of Dumbarton could be lost to the Leven, with the coastline in Helensburgh also near decimated.Picture: Climate CentralAcross the Clyde, Greenockrsquos shorefront has taken a battering under the predictions.The Waterfront and Esplanade would be unrecognisable, with Cappielow Park only narrowly missing being flooded.Further round the coast, the tourist-hotspot of the Largs coastline will be completely underwater,the predictions play true ndash with Nardinirsquos and the Ferry Terminal both being hit.Picture: Climate CentralCumbrae doesnrsquot bare much better, with large chunks of coastline predicted to be gone in just a few decades.The same can be said in Ardrossan, with the ferry terminal, Asda and the entire south beach submerged.Saltcoats Harbour is also predicted to be badly hit, reaching as far inland as the train station.Picture: Climate CentralIrvine faces a similar fate, with only areas more inland than their station also remaining unscathed.And in Ayr, key landmarks like the Racecourse and Somerset Park remain safe, but the popular beachfront, Wellington School and Newton-on-Ayr station would all be submerged.If the climate change predictions come true, the entirety of Grangemouth and much of Falkirk would be lost beneath the tidal waters of the Forth.The Kelpies would become seahorses, while the entire shoreline would be redrawn.Heading north towards Alloa, the structural integrity of the Clackmannanshire Bridge would be put into question within  years, with the study predicting it would be hit by the rising sea levels.Picture: Climate ChangeIn Alloa itself, much of the main town centre would remain unscathed,the study bares true, with places like the rugby club and Alloa Inch completely disappearing.A similar story could be told for Stirling. While much of the integrity of the town centre is safe, the iconic Wallace Monument faces being consumed by the rising waters.The study also estimates that the Kincardine Bridge would be submerged, as will most of the town.Picture: Climate CentralThe strength of the Forth Bridges will also be put into question, with rising waters predicted to hit North Queensferry, Burntisland, Kinghorn and the shoreline of Kirkcaldy.Further north, the historic Old Course at St Andrews would be lost to history,the study plays true.Picture: Climate CentralAnd in Dundee, the VA museum, the railway station, airport and the Tay Road Bridge are all in line to be hit by .Increasing sea levels would cause havoc for the likes of Montrose, with vast swathes of housing being covered by the rising waters by  ndash according to the study.Dunnottar Castle would also be at risk ndash however the predictions suggest that Aberdeen itself would remain mostly unharmed.Picture: Climate CentralA dferent story is said for Inverness, however, with the entire north of the city being covered in the rising water levels, according to the study.Across the Highlands, small patches of land near the coast are predicted to be hit.Meanwhile in the Hebrides, vast swathes of land on the west coast are predicted to be underwater, wiping out a large area of the islands.Picture: Climate CentralHowever, Climate Central admits the calculations that have led to fears of a nightmare scenario include "some error".It says: "These maps incorporate big datasets, which always include some error. These maps should be regarded as screening tools to identy places that may require deeper investigation of risk."The maps have been based on "global-scale datasets for elevation, tides and coastal flood likelihoods" and "imperfect data is used".Somewhat comfortingly, Climate Central adds: "Our approach makes it easy to map any scenario quickly and reflects threats from permanent future sea-level rise well."However, the accuracy of these maps drops when assessing risks from extreme flood events."Our maps are not based on physical storm and flood simulations and do not take into account factors such as erosion, future changes in the frequency or intensity of storms, inland flooding, or contributions from rainfall or rivers."But it adds: "Improved elevation data indicate far greater global threats from sea level rise and coastal flooding than previously thought and thus greater benefits from reducing their causes."It should be noted that these are only projections.You can view the full map here.

title: east-lothian-unemployment-figures-continue-rise
