title: cockenzie-green-data-centre-plan-branded-giant-shed
story: The latest proposal for the site, which is owned by East Lothian Council, sees it being put forward as one of  prime locations for data centres, which would operate using lsquogreenrsquo energy, by the Scottish Futures Trust.But while the trust says the site is an attractive location to support Scotlandrsquos digital ambitions, Prestonpans community councillor Calum Miller has described it as ldquoanother giant empty shed.The local authority bought the former power station and surrounding land from ScottishPower three years ago and has been marketing it as an important economic site for the county.To date, the only approved plans for the land are an unmanned substation which will bring energy onshore from a windfarm the substation has been described by Prestonpans Community Council and neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council as a ldquobig shed.The Host in Scotland initiativefor Scottish Futures Trust is partnered with Scottish Enterprise, whose original plans for a marine energy park on the site seven years ago had to be abandoned after a huge grassroots protest.: Energy park plans scrappedAlongside Crown Estate Scotland, it has published a shortlist of sites which could be green data centres, with Cockenzie number two on the list behind Chapelcross, Annan.The sites are described as offering excellent conditions which ldquocould quickly and easily lend themselves to becoming a large-scale data centrefacility.Data centres are described as buildings where large networks of computer servers are placed by companies to process and store vast amounts of data.East Lothian Council has said that delays in decisions over Cockenzie are being caused because the Scottish Government has still to decide where the site lies in its National Planning Framework plans, which are still being drawn up.In previous NPF strategies, the site has been earmarked as one of national energy importance.Mr Miller questioned why a ferry port bid backed by Prestonpans Community Council was being blocked by concern over national policy while a data centre was being pushed forward.: Cruise terminal talksHe said: ldquoItrsquos odd that NPF is such a huge blocker on a cruise ferry port but welcomes another giant empty shed here with open arms.ldquoThe data centre plan will keep Scottish bureaucrats busy in Edinburgh but it wonrsquot create many employment opportunities in Prestonpans.And he questioned whether promoting the centres in Scotland as a lsquogreenrsquo alternative would attract business.He said: ldquoIrsquove worked in IT all my le but fail to see how Scottish data centres will offer value over what Amazon Google Microsoft are already building on an international basis.ldquoGreen energy is not the market dferentiator the Scottish Government wants it to be.ldquoIT companies purchase cloud resources based on service, price, reliability, security and proximity. A data centre backed by expensive and unreliable wind energy is way down the list.Derek McCrindle,Scottish Enterprise head of place, said that the shortlist of sites would ldquoattract investors looking for a place to host data that can provide the right solutions for the climate and the economy.And the proposal was welcomed by East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill, who said: ldquoThis is a potential opportunity for the site. Itrsquos something thatrsquos lacking in Scotland and yet badly needed.ldquoIt would bring employment and yet doesnrsquot restrict additional uses. Itrsquos something that council and government must work collaboratively on.

title: uniform-swap-shop-held-prestonpans-help-children-return-school
story: Prestonpans-based Pennypit Community Development Trust launched a lsquounorm swap shoprsquo in mid-March after it was announced that children couldto school following lockdown.The unorm swap shop allows families to donate items that are no longer used for new or second-hand school unorms.Parents are encouraged to visit the stall eventhey do not have anything to donate.Lorna Bellany, Pennypit Development Trust community nutritionist, said: ldquoNot only is there a financial cost to a unorm, but right now school unorms are not in shops, few clothing stores are open and many children have outgrown their current clothes.ldquoWe advocate recycling clothes and many clothing items that children outgrow are still in good condition that others can use, and so the unorm swap-shop is open to the whole community ndash it would be amazingwe could make this a regular occurrence throughout the year.The charity, which works with families across East Lothian, has reported a high number of new referrals due to the financial strain of the Covid- pandemic.Lorna added that the charity group had received positive feedback from parents, who had been thankful to receive clothing that would benefit their children in the new school term.Parents can find skirts, shirts, trousers and school brand jumpers at the Unorm Swap Shop in all sizes.Jumpers for Preston Tower Primary and Nursery, St Gabrielrsquos Primary and Preston Lodge High School will be available for collection.The swap shop will be open tomorrow , .-.pm, and on Friday, .am-.pm at Pennypit Pagoda car park on North Grange Avenue.In line with Covid- restrictions, donated clothes will be quarantined for  hours before being handled and washed.

title: gathering-youths-drinking-longniddry-bents-an-accident-waiting-happen
story: Reports have been passed on to police and East Lothian Council Countryside Rangers after broken glass, empty bottles and cans, canisters of nitrous oxide ndash also known as laughing gas ndash and medicine packaging were all left behind close to car park No. on Saturday evening.A spokeswoman for the villagersquos community council said that there was ldquoa distinct safety issue here as substance and alcohol abuse is obviously taking place.She feared that the proximity to the sea meant it was ldquoan accident waiting to happen and told the Courier: ldquoThese youths are reported to have come from both Longniddry and Prestonpans, and certainly groups of youths were seen gathering in Longniddry late Saturday afternoon.ldquoThe rubbish left behindincluded food waste and packaging, broken glass, empty bottles, empty cans , nitrous oxide canisters, balloons, empty Ibuprofen packs, empty Paracetamol packs and miscellaneous plastic bags.ldquoThere was recent evidence that a fire had been lit.ldquoThe East Lothian Countryside Rangers have been made aware of this, as have the police.As well as the safety risk, there was also anger at the litter left behind by the group.Volunteers and residents have spent recent days cleaning up behind the group of youths.Iain Stewart, chairman of Longniddry Community Council, said: ldquoI am saddened by the mess and danger to children and pets using the Bents.ldquoOne positive action would be for East Lothian Council to place litter bins like those on Gullane beach amongst others.Mr Stewart claimed that there had been ongoing littering issues at multiple areas of Longniddry Bents in the last few months.He added: ldquoWe are so lucky to have these beautul areas and it is such a shame that people canrsquot respect them.A member of the public confirmed the youths had removed and dragged a Longniddry Golf Club sign from its original place.The issue ndash which also arose at the Bents last summer ndash was highlighted on the community councilrsquos Facebook page, with a number of people, calling for more patrols in the area in a bid to tackle the gatherings and stop the littering.One Facebook user said: ldquoIt would helpthe council would install some big bins at the car parks because the amount of rubbish and broken glass that is left daily is disgusting.Another member of the public said: ldquoThe Bents need more patrolling as the youths will not use the bins, they need to break up the mass gatherings andany of the parents do know their children are involved be more proactive.Another comment described it as ldquodisgusting behaviour, so many youngsters these days have no respect.Another comment read: ldquoAppalling behaviour, I fear for these areas in the coming weeks and months.ldquo[They] became almost unusable this time last year with all the rubbish and debris left behind, and pretty intimidating walking amongst the mass gatherings.ldquoItrsquos also very dangerous walking your dog with it all lying about and I had a vets bill to prove it!ldquoJust hope the police patrol these areas more often, even with their limited resources.Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, described the reported gathering as ldquodeeply concerning.He said: ldquoIt is a breach of the current coronavirus rules and those involved also appear to have engaged in other illegal activity.ldquoThey also left a considerable amount of rubbish, including broken glass, which poses a danger to others as well as to wildle.ldquoAs the community council has pointed out, this is a safety as well as a Covid issue, and I would encourage anyone who has information about this gathering to report it to the police.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell, Police Scotlandrsquos Local Area Commander for East Lothian, said: ldquoWe are aware of complaints of youths congregating at the beaches in large numbers and have increased patrols at the pertinent times to engage with them.ldquoThe vast majority of the youths behave in a considerate and polite manner but a small minority can cause disorder.ldquoWe will take a robust approach to any anti-social behaviour and ensure that where offences are discovered we will work with our partners to identy the culprits.ldquoWe ask that everyone continues to abide by the Scottish Government Covid- guidelines and the public should continue to report any breaches of these to police.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe are aware that coastal sites in particular are popular areas for people to congregate and are working in partnership with Police Scotland to advise visitors of current Covid restrictions, including the avoidance of crowds.

title: haddington-pubs-outdoor-tables-approved
story: The operators of the Golf Tavern, Haddington, asked East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board to let them serve food and drink at the front of the pub as lockdown eases.The pub, which sits in the heart of a residential area in the townrsquos Nungate, was describedby licensee Lynn Gordon-McIntosh as a community business which had been serving locals for more than  years.And despite one objection from residents of a property adjacent to the pub, she said that the majority of neighbours had been supportive of the plans.Mrs Gordon-McIntosh told a virtual meeting of the licensing board: ldquoWe are a community business and we have been hit hard by the pandemic.ldquoWe are trying to keep nearly  staff employed.ldquoWe have spoken to close neighbours and, apart from one objection, everyone  has wished us well.: Beer gardens to reopenThe pub applied for a permanent major iation to its operating licence to allow five picnic benches on the street in front of it and two to the side.The roads department have already approved the use of the roadway for the outdoor seating and the licence asked for the outdoor area to be used until pm for drink and pm for food.The board received a written objection from residents of one neighbouring property, who raised concern that the outdoor area would create noise and bring patrons in close proximity to their property.However, the board, after deliberating in private, approved the licence, adding an pm curfew to using the outdoor seating area.Ward councillor John McMillan, chairing the board, said: ldquoWe are minded to grant the application but with a finish time of pm bearing in mind the residential nature of the area.ldquoWe will monitor any changes and are sure they will be positive.

title: clean-bandit-headline-east-music-festival
story: Out East, due to take place on August  and , is described as a "fun-loving festival for the carefree, the intrepid and the brave", offering a "glorious blend of music, arts and culture, wellbeing, incredible food and open-air dancing".The first headliner to be announced is Ministry of Sound, a -piece orchestra performing iconic dance classics, completely rearranged and reinterpreted for .The very best tunes, say organisers, will be recreated in a breathtaking orchestral performance, set in the "socially distanced" grounds ofGosford House , by Longniddry.The second act to be announced is Clean Bandit , who have consistently pushed the boundaries of modern pop with their erse blend of influences.lsquoRather Bersquo, lsquoRockabyersquo and lsquoSymphonyrsquo are just some of the multi-million selling hits that have seen them secure nine top-five singles in the last six years.They have collaborated with artists including Jess Glynn and Sean Paul, and Julia Michaels on their most recent track lsquoI Miss You.rsquoGosford HouseShane Grieve, festival director, said: "We wanted to create something that was a celebration of good times."Wersquove sourced a mix of live performances and entertainment to make sure that therersquos something special for every member of the family.""It is also extremely important to us that we look out for each other so we have launched a friendship policy."We want everyone that visits Out East to have the best time - but not at the expense of others. There will of course be official security at the festival but wersquore asking everyone to take responsibility for their behaviour and to look out for each other."If someone canrsquot get home, are lost or are feeling vulnerable then we ask you to help us keep them safe."Find a security guard, offer them a smile - letrsquos have lots of fun and letrsquos do it together."One of the last major outdoor events to be held in the grounds of Gosford House was in October  at the Hot Dub Stein Machine music and Oktoberfest-themed beer festival.It ended in tragedy when festival-goer Scott Calder, , from Edinburgh, was found unconscious on the beach nearLongniddry BentsNo.  car park by a member of the public at about .am the next morningand later died.Local food and drink offerings as well as some surprise experiences and stages will also be on offer at Out East, say organisers.There will be a main stage, an arts and culture stage, a wellbeing area, a kids stage, food and drink area, woodland trail, and a campsite.A limited number of early bird tickets go on sale tomorrow. A weekend ticket is pound. for an adult, pound. for - year olds, while childrengo free.A day ticket is pound.  pound. youth.See www.outeastfest

title: breathalyser-stops-drink-driving-fitted-cars-uk
story: The alcolock would require drivers to blow into a breath-testing instrument in their car which is connected to the vehicle ignition system to prevent it from startingthe driver is over the limit.The Government is facing increasing pressure to tackle drink-driving on UK roads.Last year, figures from the Department for Transport revealed a  per cent rise in drink-drive crashes in the UK.The figures meant that around one in  of all reported crashes in  involved a drink driver.A report from the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safetyand IAM RoadSmart highlights how the use of alcolocks would have a positive impact on road safety.The PACTS report mirrors recent research by IAM RoadSmart of over , motorists, which reveals overwhelming support from driversto fit alcolocks in all new cars. per cent of motorists support all new cars having built-in technology that immobilises the vehiclethe driver is over the limit.lsquoAlcolocksrsquo, or alcohol ignition locks, work in a similar way to conventional breathalyser tests used by police.From next year, all new cars sold in Europe will be lsquoalcolock enabledrsquo but it is up to the Government to decide how they will be used.IAM RoadSmart has previously stated they will be a useful tool to get drink drive offenders back to safer driving after a ban.Neil Greig, IAM RoadSmart Director of Policy and Research said: ldquoWorldwide, integrating technology, such as alcolocks, with rehabilitation courses, has been shown to be the most effective way to stop drink drive reoffending and reduce crashes.ldquoSince , there have been around  deaths a year in Great Britain involving a driver over the legal drink driving limit and in contrast to the previous decade, no progress has been made in reducing these numbers.He added: ldquoThe evidence is clear. Nearly all motorists want new cars fitted with alcolocks to help stop the daily carnage on UK roads from drink driving and this latest PACTS report is even further endorsement.

title: musselburgh-lidl-expand-scottish-craft-beer
story: The discount supermarket chain asked East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board to allow it to expand the size of its alcohol section by one per cent at its Olivebank store, Musselburgh.The chain said that the move was part of its ongoing Get Fresh expansion programme for stores.And it said that the expanded aisle would be used to sell the craft drinks from Scotland.Lidlrsquos application was approved by the board this week and comes just two months after it successfully applied to expand the alcohol sales in its Prestonpans store.: Lidl accused of drinks monopolyApplying to expand in Musselburgh, Lidl said that the increase would take its normal percentage of store given over to alcohol from . per cent to . per cent, it traditionally goes up around an additional one per cent during the festive season.The chain pointed out that the amount of shelves given over to alcohol in its stores remained half of the lsquoBig Fourrsquo supermarkets, which stocked up to  per cent of their shelves with alcohol.Asking the board to approve the expansion,Lidl said that it would bring the store into line with expansions across Scotland.The chain came under fire from Prestonpans Community Council when it applied to expand in the East Lothian town, with the grouprsquos objection asking what Lidl did for the community.However, at the time, ward councillor Lachlan Bruce highlighted Lidlrsquos work supporting local community initiatives, including food donations to the Pennypit Trust.In applying for the expansion in Musselburgh, Lidl highlighted its work in the local community providing unused food through a Neighbourly scheme which partners with the Hollies Day Centre and Stoneyhill Afterschool Club in the town and Tranent Salvation Army.The board approved the expansion unanimously.

title: woodland-gifford-plays-star-role-new-movie-premiering-week
story: Edinburgh-based Grid Iron Theatre Company is getting ready for the online premiere tomorrowof Doppler: The Story So Far.Filming took place in the southern half of Fawn Woods, to the north-west of the East Lothian village, last autumn.The theatre company, featuring Outlander actor Keith Fleming as Doppler, with Itxaso Moreno and Sean Hay playing the remaining characters, was creating its own version of Norwegian writer Erlend Loersquos satirical novel Doppler.The background of the Gford woodland was to represent the forest on the edge of Oslo.Following filming, Judith Doherty, chief executive of the Edinburgh-based theatre company, highlighted the importance of the woods to the tale.She said: ldquoIt is just beautul.ldquoDoppler is about a man who decides, after a series of events happen to him in middle age, to give up a commercial lestyle and move into the forest on the edge of Oslo.ldquoWe needed a tree-covered place and somewhere that felt quite remote but the interesting thing about Doppler is that he moves to the edge of the city.ldquoHe does not move completely into the wilderness and Gford was all that and it is just beautully maintained.ldquoWe had a lovely mix of completely natural woodland and our committee were busy putting in paths and doing tree maintenance.Originally, Grid Iron had planned to present the film at last yearrsquos Edinburgh Festival Fringe.Coronavirus restrictions and filming hit by storms saw that plan shelved, with the film to be shown on the grouprsquos website.Judith added: ldquoDoppler had been in our plans for a couple of years and when Covid- hit, we really thought that, given our track-record of producing outdoor shows coupled with the ability this production would give us to physically distance the cast and crew, we had a good chance of making at least a clutch of live performances happen towards the end of August.ldquoUnfortunately, it wasnrsquot to be and we had to go with our plan B, which was a film.ldquoWhat we hadnrsquot bargained for, however, was the wonderfully timed arrival of Storm Francis!ldquoFast forward a few months and here we are, presenting Doppler: The Story So Far, which we hope gives a great insight into all the ups and downs of producing a theatre show in a global pandemic.Theatre company board member Graeme Davies, who lives in the village, had recommended Gford as a potential filming location.The crew ldquoinstantly knew it was perfect for filming and set about creating their version of Doppler.The -strong crew made their way to Gford last August and spent a week in the village, staying in the Tweeddale Arms and Goblin Harsquo. The first screening takes place at pm tomorrow at www.gridiron.org.ukDetails can be found and screening will take place on www.gridiron.org.uk

title: north-berwick-named-best-place-live-scotland-sunday-times
story: It has been placed top of a list of eight locations across Scotland chosen to represent the best of Britain in the annual Sunday Times Best Places to Live guide.The guide was released online todayand will be available in print this weekend.The judges said of the East Lothian town: ldquoMaybe itrsquos the energy radiating from North Berwick Law, a #million-year-old volcanic plug that stands brooding over the town, or the profusion of yoga teachers practising downward-facing dogs at the Barefoot Sanctuary event space near Milsey Bay beach. Either way, therersquos no denying the spiritual aura of North Berwick.They went on to describe the town as an ldquoelegant seaside resort that has been luring jaded urbanities from Edinburgh and beyond for decades.Its shoreline and the nearby Bass Rock were also mentioned, alongside North Berwick High School, considered one of the best in the country ndash in The Sunday Timesrsquo Scottish school league table last year it was ranked th out of  schools for pupils achieving five or more Highers.But it was not just the schoolrsquos academic achievements ndash pupils were praised for their sense of social justice and charity work, and the school prioritising pupilsrsquo mental health, such as with the launch of its new wellbeing microsite.The judges also said that the townrsquos ldquoaltruistic attitude is contagious, making a mention of the local stores that offered home delivery services during lockdown and the vast array of coffee shops on offer to visitors.The average house price was listed as pound,, with the average rent price pound, per month, the second highest of all places on the shortlist.North Berwick HarbourJoining the popular seaside town on the list of eight are :To view the list in full, visit thetimes best-places-to-LiveThe Sunday Timesrsquo team of expert judges behind the guide assess a range of factors, from schools, air quality, transport and broadband speeds to culture, green spaces and the health of the high street.The judges look for improving towns, villages or city centres, for attractive, well-designed homes and locations that are bursting with community spirit ndash something proven to be vital during the coronavirus pandemic.A detailed breakdown of house prices was supplied by data specialists TwentyCi and information on internet speeds from thinkbroadband, the UKrsquos leading independent guide to broadband.Helen Davies, The Times and Sunday Times property editor, said: ldquoThis guide has never been so important.ldquoThe pandemic has taught us just how much we rely on our homes, our communities and our surroundings.ldquoWith working from home now common, itrsquos no surprise that many of us are reassessing our priorities and thinking hard about where we really want to live.ldquoOur focus for this year has been community, countryside and convenience. It hasnrsquot been a year for big cities or small villages. Instead, it is small towns that have shone: big enough to have everything you need within walking distance and small enough for everyone to feel connected.ldquoNorth Berwick is our winner in Scotland because it is one place that really does have it all: heavenly beaches, jaw-dropping views from North Berwick Law, a successful secondary school and a lively high street.Stroud in Gloucestershire was named as the Best Place to Live in Britain.

title: iain-gray-msps-final-column-its-honour-serve-east-lothian-14-years
story: You can be sure, though, it is my last column. After  years in politics, the last  of them representing East Lothian in Holyrood, I am retiring ndash officially on May , the day before the election, but from today we are in election lsquorecessrsquo, so no more columns.It has been the privilege of my le to represent East Lothian ndash the best place to live, work or even just visit in the whole of Scotland ndash at Holyrood. I have tried hard every day of those  years to put East Lothian first, to be the strongest voice I can for this constituency.I have been helped by so many people who make this county great ndash local businesses, churches, schools, sports clubs, charities and countless community groups so many people looking out for family, friends and neighbours, keeping our communities strong and supportive, for the most part with little thanks or recognition.Thank you to you, the voters of East Lothian, for allowing me this honour.Of course, I hope to pass the baton on to Martin Whitfield, the Labour candidate in the election, but whoever you choose, their priority should be ensuring these local heroes and heroines in every one of our towns and villages get the support they need.Nationally, the new parliamentrsquos focus must be rebuilding after the pandemic, not another referendum.I want to thank my constituency office staff, who have done the real work for the past  years. If we managed to help you, the credit is theirs. If we could not, the fault was mine!Finally, a mention for the newspaper you are reading. The Courier is one of the things which keeps our communities strong, a vital local channel of information. So, please keep buying the paper and reading this column, whoever is writing it.

title: plea-owners-dogs-disturbing-birds-levenhall-links-nature-reserve
story: Posters have been put up at Levenhall Links in support of the Responsible Dog Ownership Campaign, launched by the Scottish Government in partnership with the Scottish SPCA.The initiative seeks to remind dog owners that they have a legal responsibility to keep their dog under proper control in order to prevent and reduce the risk of incidents.The posterswere put up at the nature attraction ndash which once hosted RSPB Scotlandrsquos Big Nature Festival ndash by East Lothian Councilrsquos countryside rangers, who are also targeting other sites in the county.A council spokeswoman said that, as the weather improved, the days ened and people exercised outdoors, it was appropriate to remind dog walkers to keep dogs under control.She said: ldquoAt this time of year in countryside sites there may be young birds or nests that can be disturbed by dogs running off lead.ldquoThe posters are to remind dog owners to keep their pets close to hand and not to encourage behaviour that may cause problems to wildle or indeed other visitors.ldquoThis issue of countryside disturbance is not unique to Levenhall Links or East Lothian but is recognised throughout the UK as more people are accessing the countryside than ever before and are unaware of how their actions can have an adverse impact on wildle.ldquoIt has been estimated around . million pets had been bought in the UK during lockdown. Potentially, thatrsquos a lot of new dogs out in the countryside and a lot of new owners who are not necessarily aware of appropriate behaviour for their pet.Levenhall Links is a bird reserve within a Site of Special Scientic Interest which, at the access point, has a large wooden sign advising people to stay on the path and to use the hides to observe birds.A peregrine falcon hunting over the bird reserve. Image: Ian AndrewsThe council spokesperson said: ldquoUnfortunately, both people and dogs are walking off the paths and disturbing ious species of birds. One is the issue of ground nesting birds. We are entering the breeding season and last year was a very poor year for ground nesting birds, which is thought to be largely due to disturbance.ldquoSkylarks, meadow pipit and grey partridge are the key species in Musselburgh that suffer from disturbance.ldquoThe key message is lsquoareas of uncut coastal grassland may have nesting birds presentrsquo. Try to avoid these areas between April  and July , and stick to areas of cut grasslandyou wish to exercise your dog off-lead.The bird reserve at the lagoons is a wetland bird reserve, with wading birds roosting and feeding.ldquoOut-of-control dogs out of their ownerrsquos sight are having a negative impact, said the council spokesperson.One local birdwatcher recently tweeted about disturbance, which was retweeted by naturalist and television presenter Chris Packham and generated a lot of discussion.The council spokesperson said: ldquoIt seems  was a bad year for wildle throughout the whole of the UK due to more people out and about. The message is to think about where to walk your dog. Try to avoid estuaries where birds are feeding and remember that nature reserves and coastal grassland are sensitive areas.Jason Rose, chairman of community group Friends of Musselburgh Links, said: ldquoThis has been an issue on and off over the years but does seem to have got worse in recent weeks. Putting up fresh signs to make things clearer should help.ldquoItrsquos really importantyou bring dogs to the lagoons, whether you are the owner or a commercial walker, you stay away from the wader scrapes. There is fencing all the way round this area for a reason.ldquoThere is plenty of space where on the links to exercise dogs. Many owners are responsible, and we thank them.ldquoHowever, I also know that, on occasion, when a dog walker has been approached about disruptive behaviour, they have shown disinterest in the issue. These incidents clearly arenrsquot accidents and thatrsquos heartbreaking.ldquoThe lagoons are a Site of Special Scientic Interest and there were already prominent signs making this clear, asking people to stick to the paths and keep quiet. Dogs off the lead in this area will cause ground-nesting birds to scatter, leaving eggs and chicks vulnerable. This could be devastating for future populations of wildle which bring so much joy.

title: liberal-democrats-announce-candidate-midlothian-north-musselburgh-seat
story: Liberal Democrat Charles Dundas, a former City of Edinburgh councillor, has pledged to prioritise recovering from the Covid- pandemic.He said: ldquoCovid- has drastically affected our health service, our economy, and the world of education ndash and getting all of them back on track should be at the heart of what the next Scottish Government focuses on.ldquoThe Scottish Liberal Democrats have just one political priority at this time ndash recovering from the pandemic crisis.Mr Dundas, a history graduate from the University of Glasgow, has worked as an accountant for the National Australia Bank and researcher in the Scottish Parliament.He was also a consultant for a commercial public affairs firm.He is currently chief executive of the Borders Forest Trust and is a former trustee of the Royal Lyceum Theatre.In his spare time, Mr Dundas performs locally and abroad with an improv troupe and has appeared at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a number of times.: Conservatives, Labour and SNP announce Midlothian North and Musselburgh candidatesBetween  and  he was elected to City of Edinburgh Council, where he chaired the Administration group and served on the planning committee as well as the transport, environment and infrastructure committee, and the education committee. He was also a member of the Lothian and Borders Police Board.Mr Dundas said: ldquoMidlothian North and Musselburgh deserves an MSP who prioritises those issues which are most important to our daily lives and not one who just wants to play with the endless political footballs of Brexit or independence. I want to see the Scottish Liberal Democrats elected and able to boost Scotlandrsquos mental health services, to create jobs and to help pupils catch up.ldquoAs a committed environmentalist, I am also determined that our recovery from the pandemic should go hand in hand with the urgent recovery that Scotlandrsquos nature needs to help us tackle the climate emergency.ldquoWe have a big job ahead of uswe want to build a Scotland that we can be proud to pass to on to the generations to come but our most important priority should be putting recovery first.Also contesting the seat at the election is sitting MSP Colin Beattie , Midlothian councillor Stevie Curranand City of Edinburgh councillor Iain Whyte .The nomination period closes on Wednesday.

title: st-marys-parish-church-haddington-welcome-back-worshippers-holy-week
story: St Maryrsquos Parish Church will open its doors for a public service for the first time this year, with a Palm Sunday service this weekend.Coronavirus restrictions meant that churches across the country were closed last year for Holy Week and Easter.Now, the Haddington church, which closed again ahead of the festive period, is getting ready to welcome back a limited number of people, with ious restrictions still to be followed.The Rev Alison McDonald, minister at the church, said: ldquoWe discovered together the truth of saying that the Easter Gospel lives outside our building. We find it in our hearts, in our homes, our community, wherever new le springs up through faith and love, hope and joy rise up, despite the many things which might hold them down.ldquoThe same is true this year when our church building will be open for worship, Covid- rates permitting.ldquoSt Maryrsquos will be filled with the sound of Easter music , the Easter Gospel will be proclaimed, and we will praise God who raised Jesus Christ from the dead.The service gets under way at am, with the strict attendance limit in place.Those attending are asked not to enter the buildingthey have any coronavirus symptoms or are feeling unwell.In addition, face coverings must be worn at all times and a two-metre distance from people not from the same household must also be maintained.Anyone attending must wash or sanitise their hands before entering the building and provide details for Test  Protect.Singing is also not permitted, with congregation members directed to their seats by stewards.The minister added: ldquoThe fact that we are open this year is good news, not just for ourselves.ldquoIt means that enough progress has been made in containing the spread of the virus to allow it to happen.ldquoTuesday marks a year since the first national lockdown began.ldquoThe pandemic has cost the lives of over , people in the UK, and the scale of loss globally is dficult to take in. The response to the pandemic has also been remarkable from our health and care workers, scientists and researchers, and in every community where people have supported one another and dug deep.To join the Sunday service, call or text   -am or -pm todayto book.Registration for Easter Sunday will open next Friday.

title: virtual-lands-end-john-ogroats-walk-help-preston-lodge-high-school-pipe-band
story: Pipe Major Lee Moore is among a group of  looking to raise thousands of pounds to buy unorms for members of Preston Lodge High School Pipe Band.The fundraisers are walking  miles ndash the distance from Landrsquos End to John OrsquoGroats ndash with each unorm costing between pound and pound.Mr Moore , who has been the pipe major for about  years, told the Courier: ldquoDuring lockdown, I, like many others, have been doing a lot of walking and getting out, especially with teaching being online for so long.ldquoYou need a break and some fresh air every wee while to get rid of screen fatigue.ldquoWe have been stepping it up, and myself and band secretary Catriona Black had a wee competition to see who could do the most steps each day.ldquoI spotted on Facebook the idea of the lsquoend to end challengersquo from Landrsquos End to John OrsquoGroats virtually.ldquoI signed up and told Catriona and she signed up too.ldquoWe decided we would do it as a kind of sponsored walk to get some cash in for the unorms we were looking for.ldquoWe told the parents about it and eight of them have signed up.The challenge got under way at the beginning of the month, with each of the  walkers already beyond the -mile mark.Mr Moore highlighted that the walking had opened his eyes to what was on offer in Musselburgh, where he lives.He had enjoyed walking ldquosporadically but was now enjoying the great outdoors.The -year-old said: ldquoIt has been great. You discover lots of stuff in your own locality that you never knew before and Irsquove seen all seasons.ldquoI regularly walk up along the side of the Esk ndash you just see it all.Walkers are aiming to reach the virtual finish line by the end of August, with hopes of the band marching through Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, and Longniddry later in the year.The fundraisers are looking to raise pound, for the band, with more than pound, already donated by generous members of the public.The band, which has about  members, is made up of pipers and drummers from throughout the Preston Lodge school cluster.Mr Moore was looking forward to members being able to get back together, with the bandrsquos last performance having been on St Patrickrsquos Day in Portobello last year.He said: ldquoIt has been very hard. title: response-covid-19-differed-around-world
story: Countries around the world have struggled to control the deadly virus which has claimed lives across the globe.Measures taken to tackle the health crisis dfered from country to country but what have we learned about how nationshave handled the largest health crisis in memory Thomas Hale, Associate Professor in Public Policy at the University of Oxford has tried to answer the question in a piece for The Conversation.Read what he learned here:In March , as COVID- swept around the globe, my colleagues and I began debating the bewildering new measures popping up around the world with our masterrsquos students in a politics of policymaking class at the Blavatnik School of Government at Oxford University.We had a lot of questions. Why were governments doing dferent things  Which policies would work  We didnrsquot know. And to answer those questions, we needed comparable information on these new policies, including school closings, stay at home orders, contact tracing and more.A few weeks later, we launched theOxford COVID- Government Response Trackerto help find these answers. It has now become thelargest repositoryof global evidence relating to pandemic policies.To date, more than  data collectors from around the world have helped us track  dferent categories of coronavirus response, including lockdown, health, economic, and now vaccine policies in  countries.We then group those policies into a number of indices, including the stringency index, which records the number and intensity of closure and containment policies on a scale of zero to . Fteen countries reached  on the stringency index, while seven never surpassed . The countries with the highest average stringency were Honduras, Argentina, Libya, Eritrea and Venezuela. Those with the lowest were Nicaragua, Burundi, Belarus, Kiribati and Tanzania.A year on, what  have we learned about how governments have handled the largest health crisis in memory One surprising observation is that similarities can actually outweigh dferences. During the first months of the pandemic, governments mostly adopted similar policies, in mostly the same sequence, at mostly the same time ndash thetwo middle weeks of March .This policy convergence contrasts with the uneven spread of COVID- around the world. In March , though the disease was already prevalent in some parts of Asia, and rapidly spreading in parts of Europe and North America, it had yet to reach a wide scale of transmission in many parts of the world. The global lockdown rush therefore contrasted with the ying epidemiological situations countries faced. This meant that some countries locked down too late, and others arguably too soon.But as the pandemic progressed, countries ndash and, in some parts of the world,statesandregionsndash began to y considerably.Some governments were able to contain the first wave and then preserve those gains with a mix of targeted closure and containment measures, extensive testing and contact tracing, and firm international border controls.Places likeChina,Taiwan,VietnamandNew Zealandall managed not just to flatten the curve but to keep it flat, albeit with a few small flare-ups. In our data, we count  countries that have only experienced one wave of disease, though limited testing and reporting systems, or government suppression of information, make it hard to determine the true number.Other countries have had less success, seeing second, third, or even fourth waves of disease. Some of these have been relatively small outbreaks, controllable with test and trace measures and targeted restrictions. For example,South KoreaandFinland, though not able to eliminate the virus, have largely kept it from stressing health systems.Rollercoaster countries" alt"East Lothian Courier: Many countries have seen more than one wave of the virus. " class"editor-image"Many countries have seen more than one wave of the virus. Too many countries have been on a veritable rollercoaster of rising and falling infections with corresponding policy whiplash and tragic death tolls. TheUnited States,United Kingdom,South Africa,Iran,BrazilandFrancehave seen successive waves of disease and have phased in and out of restrictive policies.Though initially debated, thescientic literatureis now clear: COVID- restrictions work to break the chain of infection, with timely, sharper restrictions having greater effect than slower, weaker ones.But while clearly true on average, there is no guarantee this recipe will always work. Countries likePerusuffered rising disease despite restrictive policies, perhaps showing that compliance and trust are also key to effectiveness. Some evidence also suggests thatstronger economic support makes COVID- restrictions more effective.Money isnrsquot everything" alt"East Lothian Courier: Money isnt everything when it comes to tacking a health crisis. " class"editor-image"Money isnt everything when it comes to tacking a health crisis. While we can identy patterns of successful response, it is also evident that none of the country characteristics that wereexpected to provide an advantagebefore the pandemic, such as wealth or autocracy, have clearly done so.If you ide the world into countries with above average and below average deaths, robust government responses and weak ones, you will find in both groups plenty of rich countries and poor countries, democracies and dictatorships, those ruled by populists and those governed by technocrats.Success and failure are moving targets. As the pandemic has evolved, so have government responses. According to our data, vaccines are now available in  countries and rising. Notably, some of the countries most swtly rolling out vaccination ndash Israel, the UK, the United States, the UAE ndash are places that have previously struggled to control the virus through restrictions and test-and-trace systems.Lessons for the future" alt"East Lothian Courier: Boris Johnson reflects on one year since the first lockdown. " class"editor-image"Boris Johnson reflects on one year since the first lockdown. One year on, the pandemic is by no means over, but already our data suggests someimplications and lessonsfor governments.First, old ideas about what contributes to pandemic preparedness need to be updated. Some countries with formidable scientic and healthcare capacitystumbled mightily. At the same time, places with less capacity, includingMongolia,ThailandandSenegalhave managed to largely keep people healthy and the economy running.Second, learning from others, or even from past experience, cannot be taken for granted. In March  eastern European countries like theCzech Republic, Hungary, and Bulgariasaw what happened to their western neighbours and imposed restrictions before community transmission became widespread. They largely avoided the death tolls many western European countries experienced in the first wave.But then just a few months later some of the same eastern European countries did the exact opposite, waiting too long to reimpose measures as cases rose in the autumn, with all too predictable consequences.Finally, while our work has tracked inidual governmentsrsquo responses, it is clear that exiting the pandemic will require global cooperation. Until transmission is curtailed throughout the world with restrictions and vaccinations, therisk of new iantssending us back to square one cannot be ignored.In the first year of the pandemic we saw little cooperation between governments. In the next, we will need to work together to control this disease.

title: old-firm-coronavirus-avoid-disgraceful-scenes-brian-taylor
story: This week a new challenge emerged to those endeavours, a new problem from the world of football. That problem continues to pose concerns, not least over whether the sizeable gatherings outside Ibrox and in Glasgowrsquos George Square might be repeated, perhaps at the upcoming Old Firm match.I watched Celtic draw with Dundee United last weekend, a result which guaranteed the Premiership for Rangers. Football fans will perhaps understand that my first thought was that my team, United, now had virtually no chance of securing a top six place in the league, and thus avoiding a possible relegation battle. BRIAN TAYLOR:This is not a civil war in the SNP. This is more vicious and more visceralHowever, the wider consequences soon emerged as Rangers fans mustered to celebrate their teamrsquos success, in clear breach of rules prohibiting mass gatherings.Condemnation was swt from the First Minister, Opposition leaders and the police. While praising Rangersrsquo sporting achievement, they declared that the supportersrsquo actions were unacceptable and dangerous. They reminded us bluntly that closely packed crowds had the potential to spread disease and even death.Let us be clear. Parliament has the democratic power to prescribe rules. Within those rules, the police have a duty to proscribe behaviour which threatens the peace and, in this case, the health of citizens. Law and order must be maintained.The question is how. What is the truly effective way to prevent repetition  To do that, we need to understand the motivations underlying the behaviour we all witnessed.Otherwise, we risk making matters worse, we risk reinforcing a negative stereotype. To say this is in no way ndash I stress, in no way whatsoever ndash to condone the behaviour on display. It was dangerous and, potentially, deadly.Nicola Sturgeon has warned the Old FirmFirstly, I would broadly exculpate the police. You will hear it said either that they over-reacted or that they should have made far more arrests.The police did not create the situation. The fans gathered instinctively, emotively, no doubt prompted by social media. The police had to deal with events as they found them.An over-zealous response would have risked provoking the crowd, amplying the challenge to public order. Precisely the opposite of what the police were seeking to achieve.Secondly, consider the intrinsic nature of football support. We are dealing here with fans, or fanatics. For many, their le is defined by their vigorous adherence to their team. They exult in victory, they despair at defeat.This particular triumph for Rangers followed a decade without winning the league title a decade in which they had to rise from the lowest rank in Scottish football. In winning, they thwarted their greatest rivals.More generally, many fans regard their support for their team in an antithetical fashion to rival clubs, or even to society more generally. It is no accident that many supporters sing ldquonobody likes us, we donrsquot care. Their contrived self-image is as a beleaguered tribe, standing together against an external foe or an uncaring world.That is true of the most fervent of fans generally but it is particularly true of the Old Firm. Their adherents will often define themselves in contradistinction to the other side. Which can present a challenge for neutral observers or, indeed, for politicians seeking to intervene.Grimacing wryly, Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs this week that half of Glasgow presumed she was partisan for one side of the Old Firm while the other half presumed exactly the contrary. She was, she stressed, unconcerned about the colour of the shirt.It was also notable in Rangersrsquo official statement that they immediately drew attention to what they regarded as ldquoan unbalanced approach adopted towards their half of the Old Firm.In that same statement, Rangers insisted they had taken every step to pre-empt and deter such behaviour. It might be pertinent to note here that broader support for that analysis is distinctly limited. Further, eventhey were doing all they could, then those efforts demonstrably failed.Crucially, however, Rangers supporters will agree with their club. They will discern bias against them which others do not spot. Such a standpoint is not entirely unknown on the other side of the Glasgow sporting ide, nor indeed in football more generally. They are not known as fans for nothing. Once again, that does not remotely exonerate the behaviour we witnessed.However, it is also the case that there are many Rangers fans who will regret the scenes witnessed, who will seek to dispel any bad odour lingering around their clubrsquos remarkable success. As The Herald reported, supportersrsquo groups have raised thousands of pounds to repair damaged benches in George Square.Equally, though, those of us who are football fans need to reflect that many, perhaps most, people in Scotland are not. BRIAN TAYLOR:Sturgeonrsquos inquiry performance was thorough, respectful, controlled and capableRemember Brenda from Bristol  On being told that a further General Election was pending, she replied: ldquoYoursquore joking! What, another one !Translate that from Brendarsquos broad Bristol accent into Scots, and you have it pat. For many in Scotland, their reaction to another controversy in football is ennui. They find it weary, stale and flat full of sound and fury and signying nothing.In that light, we now need action which will be effective, rather than simply voluble. Perhaps a promise of substantial celebrations deferred, linked to the warning that the Old Firm game may have to be cancelled. Perhaps a reminder of possible sanctions by the European football authority.It will not be sufficient for that message to be delivered solely by politicians. Still less, by the police. That will not work with the truly zealous.Football leaders must douse their instinctive indignation and urge compliance. Consistently and without equivocation. In tandem with politicians and the police. It may be exasperating that such effort is required but anything  risks further failure. Understand, then act.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

story: May , ldquoYou must fall on your sword, they urged. And get this: ldquoThe future of Scottish independence is at stake. And donrsquot you even think about it, Russell. Yoursquod be teaching Ned Latin to day-releasers on a Highlands and Islands facilitator course.Swinney was now starting to hyper-ventilate and Russell began mouthing something about Roman consuls and hot baths, the pompous old glove-puppet. Smith had been brought in to give the impression that the progressives were in on this too, but now he was actually crying and saying ldquothis is the worst day of my le since I had to hand back the keys of my Brussels apartment.ldquoIrsquom going nowhere, I told them. ldquoAndany of you even think about trying to stage a coup and replace me with that smug carpet-bagger Robertson well, think again. I know where all the bodies are buried because I f***ing buried them. Wee Kate Forbes would wipe the floor with the lot of you anyway and thatrsquos why shersquoll be succeeding me. But only when I say so.Read more:Does Nicola Sturgeon really think the voters are all stupid And so I survived my ambush by the men in grey suits. At least the ones who forced out Thatcher had the decency to wear some quality threads. This lot turned up trying to look authoritative in Matalan and River Island. Irsquove seen meaner-looking space-hoppers.Look, I know that people see me and Peter and think wersquore an odd pairing: him, the high-flying technocrat who could have had his pick of top positions at the Co-op funeral parlours and juicy store managerships at Amazon me, the couthy Ayrshire lass with the killer Louboutins. But isnrsquot it amazing how much a little black book of low crimes and misdemeanours stretching back through your long years as Chief Executive works as an aphrodisiac That insidious wee rattlesnake Harvey had even tried to muscle in on the action. Apparently, Robertson had promised him ring-fenced funding for glamping-pod and bivouac developments on the edge of our biggest towns and cities to ease the social housing crisis. There would be no cars or street-lighting and large pits containing sustainable chemicals would serve as the worldrsquos first open-air, non-binary toilet facilities so that we could meet our carbon reduction targets.The wee man is the only politician in the UK who thinks anyonersquos actually serious about the climate change grt, but it comes in handy when we need his votes to get the budgets through. Yoursquove no idea what wersquove had to promise him to shut him up. My favourite was the funding for portable chip-oil converters for every household in Possilpark and Easterhouse as a pilot scheme for renewable petrol sources.Read more:Third World debt: Our indference to global need willto haunt usAnd so, to paraphrase Gloria Gaynor, I did survive. And now theyrsquore all glad I did. The last five years havenrsquot been half bad: we keep asking for the Section s and Boris keeps knocking them back. And so the pension-pots keep boiling away nicely and we get to pretend wersquore really annoyed about it. Meanwhile that light in Brussels has been on so long that Harviersquos beginning to ask questions about unnecessary energy consumption.Humzarsquos Hate Crime Bill has settled down quite nicely too. Wersquove created , new jobs in the Hate Crime Monitor Sector and the official state-approved Catholic Church carried our -point inclusion plan. This included them agreeing to change the intro to the Lordrsquos Prayer and declaring Francis of Assisi to be the worldrsquos first transgender saint. That way, they got to keep their faith schools.The re-training camps, which we sub-contracted to the Hunter Foundation, have also been a huge success. We fast-tracked their planning applications for leadership centres on many of our major lochs so that poor families could enjoy a two-week break in remote rural settings while learning citizenship classes from the Little Red Book of Kindness.The new powers for Police Scotland have gone down well too. That  per cent pay rise across the board has worked a treat and theyrsquove been reassuringly assiduous about breaking up protests by more than  people on the old Covid iant pretext.Of course, wersquore still using the EU to keep the wider movement on the teat. Admittedly, their decision to do away with Greece and force Latvia and Estonia into giant forced labour camps to service their debts to the Bundesbank was a tough sell but wersquove found thatyou keep banging on about Erasmus ndash evenno-one knows what it means ndash it becomes like a wee, holy grail.The plan to nationalise Celtic and Rangers and merge them hasnrsquot yet cut down hate crime as our hate monitors have reported the increased presence of the flags of Beitar Jerusalem FC and Hilal Al-Quds FC as well as Lazio and Roma. The decision to work with Interpol and MI in the apprehension of the Rev Stuart Campbell was a success, although his most fervent disciples regularly report sightings of him despite the CIA assuring us of his successful rendition in Guantanamo Bay.A new book, Das Kapitalistsuccessfully takes the radical edge off Marx and recalibrates it for an enlightened, inclusive and inclusively enlightened Scotland. The editing  was brought together by Charlotte Street Partners under the chairmanship of the Duke of Buccleuch and sponsored by Aberdeen Asset Management.The Covid Mental Health co-ordinator Jason Leitchrsquos new game show: Hands, Face and Oops-a-daisy sees groups of elderly and vulnerable people given heavy doses of the Covid but their chances of survival are improved the more they stick to the rules. The longer they survive sees them win major prizes for their families. Itrsquos a great way of relieving pressure on the care home sector while reinforcing good public health messages.Saor Alba.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: gardening-eight-best-small-gardens-visit-summer
story: Therersquos a feelgood factor to visiting an open garden in the National Garden Schemetoo, as your ticket entry helps to raise money for nursing and health charities. Small gardens which are opening up to the public in conjunction with the NGS feature everything from glorious windowsill pots to quirky recyclables, including brightly-painted ladders, reclaimed mirrors and bird cages, and therersquos even an impressive little railway cottage front garden, thatrsquos been transformed into an edible paradise.If you canrsquot get to the gardens, many of them are open virtually through the NGS website , to give you ideas for your own planting, colour schemes and style.If you do want to go, yoursquoll need to book a pre-timed entry slot and check the NGS website and its Scottish counterpart SGSfor updates on Covid- restrictions.Some of the highlights include... Burnton Road, Dalrymple, AyrshireIf yoursquore after some exotic inspiration, this garden , opening for the first time under Scotlandrsquos Gardens Scheme, features tropical ideas in a tiny slice of jungle, nestled within a small triangular plot. Planting includes palms, bamboos and tree ferns, as well as hardy and tender bromeliads, while flower highlights are provided by lilies, cannas and gingers.GARDENERrsquoS COTTAGE Crombie, DunfermlineOriginally part of the Craigflower Estate, the garden was transformed by the late Scottish-German botanist Ursula McHardy to demonstrate models of natural vegetation patterns of the Southern Hemisphere.Within the walled garden you will find an Australian eucalyptus forest and a South American forest with southern beeches and monkey-puzzles. There is also a South African area and a New Zealand section with five pools as well as traditional mixed borders.DUNDONNELL HOUSE Little Loch Broom, Wester RossCamellias, magnolias and bulbs in spring, rhododendrons and laburnum walk in this ancient walled garden.Exciting planting in new borders gives all year colour centred around one of the oldest yew trees in Scotland. Itrsquos large at  acres but you can take each element as an inspiration for a smaller plot. Therersquos a new water sculpture, midsummer roses, and a recently restored unique Victorian glass house. Falconer Road, HertsThis is such a quirky garden, replete with painted ladder, right, bird cages, mirrors and other antiquarian ephemera and objets drsquoart, which interior designer owner Suzette Fuller has picked up from her customersrsquo cast-offs over the years. Planting comprises old-fashioned favourites, including hollyhocks, foxgloves and dianthus, along with more than  hanging baskets, which are peppered throughout the garden. Highfield Road, Macclesfield, CheshireIt may be a small terraced garden, left, but it packs a huge punchyou love structural planting featuring agapanthus and other striking plants in pots, at the front of an impressive vista of shrubs and herbaceous plants. The owner knows her plants ndash shersquos an RHS Certicate holder and it shows, as she combines formality with a more relaxed look, inspired by Christopher Lloyd. Fir St, Sheffield, South YorkshireThis is one of two small urban gardens, designed and owned by members of the Department of Landscape Architecture at the University of Sheffield. Anyone interested in naturalistic planting will appreciate the meadow-style design packed with plants, many of which are native to South Africa, which are usually considered too tender for a northern English city, but which will give you colour and leaf interest from February to November.

title: plenty-losers-no-winners-sorry-salmond-sturgeon-saga
story: The sceptical viewer thinks, "What have they got to congratulate themselves about  That mess is going to take more than a couple of buckets of sand to fix."For mangled Manhattan and a smug Captain America, substitute Holyrood and Nicola Sturgeon this week following the publication of two reports on her conduct during the Salmond saga. If that is success, First Minister, I would hate to see what failure looks like.The Hamilton report, it is true, said Ms Sturgeon did not breach the ministerial code. But there was that memory lapse about a key meeting there was scope for political criticism of the way the allegations against the former First Minister Alex Salmond were handled and the claim that a complainerrsquos name was leaked by one of Ms Sturgeonrsquos staff was termed ldquocredible. Hardly the most glowing report card.The second report, from a Scottish Parliament committee, was openly critical of the First Minister and officials for creating a fatally flawed complaints process, misleading parliament, obstructing and delaying the inquiryrsquos investigation, and wasting public money by carrying on with a legal battle that was clearly lost early on.: Case closed but damage doneThat last error cost well in excess of half a million pounds of your money and mine. But let us not forget, as the committeersquos report concluded: ldquoThis is not just about procedures or public money. It is about ensuring that, in the future, anyone complaining about sexual harassment is not let down in the way these women have been.Exactly. At the centre of all this should be the two women civil servants who originally brought forward complaints against Mr Salmond. From then until now they have been treated almost as an afterthought. Collateral damage in the many battles waged between parties and among former friends. That says a lot about the woeful conduct of the Scottish Government, and the goings on at the committee itself, with the final insult to the two women the leaking of their evidence to a Sunday newspaper.The womenrsquos evidence says even more. First is the matter of where it is positioned. It takes until page  of a -page report to reach the testimony of Ms A and Ms B. They were the last to give evidence, so chronologically speaking it was correct to have them just before the annexes, but as a metaphor it is unfortunate to say the least.The evidence of Ms A and Ms B is also well worth exploring for what they have to say about the workings of a Government, and a civil service, in which the leading figures were, in the latter stages of events, women.: Verdict to trust most is that of Sturgeons peersIt is ironic but true that the main mistakes took place on the watch of Ms Sturgeon as First Minister and Leslie Evans as the Permanent Secretary to the Scottish Government, the nationrsquos most senior civil servant no less.This could simply be one of those coincidences that history delights in. It is certainly something that has not merited much,any, discussion, despite the hundreds of thousands of words expended on this saga.As the committee says earlier on in its report, it was right for the Scottish Government to review its procedures in light of the #MeToo movement, and crucial to get the process right.ldquoThese were the first complaints to be taken forward under this new procedure and they were signicant in terms of the person being complained about. It was imperative that everything was done to make sure that the procedure was robust and fair and, just as importantly, seen to be robust and fair.Robust and fair ndash remember that.Ms A and Ms B were highly critical of the culture that had been allowed to grow up and operate at the time of the alleged incidents. One said: ldquoLeslie Evans, as permanent secretary, talked about the concept that what you permit, you promote. I have always thought that that is quite a nice encapsulation of this, and I think that it is a sad indictment of what happened at that time that such behaviour was permitted and a blind eye was turned to it.What you permit you promote ndash remember that.: David Leask - this is a disinformation eventAs for what happened later, one witness said: ldquoI was quite taken aback by the lack of contact and support from the Scottish Government after the conclusion of its process. We were given regular updates over the period of the judicial review, but after that we were basically just dropped.Dropped ndash remember that.Now, it could just as well have been men at the head of Government and the civil service when these things happened. Moreover, women should never be blamed, or have to apologise for, the actions of men. But equally when they get things wrong they should accept responsibility.Ms Sturgeon has indeed said sorry to the two women who came forward, and to the wider Scottish public, when she gave evidence to the Holyrood committee. Yet her contrition amounts to little in comparison to the way she has reacted to criticism in general. In parliament this week she accused opponents of trying to bully her out of office. How do you bully the head of a Government  Holding a Minister to account is not bullying.Sometimes the best thing for a leader to do is own their mistakes and move on. Yet I do not think we are about to see that idea in action as the election campaign takes hold, which is a pity.From the start of this business I have worried about its impact on girls and women thinking of coming into politics or seeking high office. Scottish politics has been left looking a gladiatorial arena in which only the strong survive, and where might ultimately poses as right, even when it is wrong.For the record, I believe that Ms Sturgeon and Ms Evans acted with the best of intentions. But mistakes were made. Huge, costly, hurtful mistakes. Yet everyone keeps their job, their high salaries, and their gold-plated pensions. Whether it was women in charge, or men, that cannot be right or fair.

title: linda-bauld-no-lockdown-baby-boom-scots-birth-rate-declines-lockdown
story: Declining birth rates are part of a longer term trend, but studies from the US and Europe suggest that the coronavirus crisis may be making this worse. Births in Italy reduced by % at the start of this year and in Spain by %. The NRS figures are the first sign that this is happening here. Speculation that lockdown might leave couples with little to do than spend time in the bedroom now seems a bit far fetched.Has the pandemic affected fertility rates, and will this drop continue To understand this better, I spoke to Professor Michael Anderson who for the past  years has studied the population history of Scotland. I asked him about this reduction and where it fits in with what we know about the factors that influence population projections. LINDA BAULD:How likely are we to catch coronavirus outdoors Professor Anderson, working with Dr Esther Roughsedge from National Records Scotland, recently reviewed some of the data. Looking at trends back to , their analysis shows that there were signicant reductions in births during both world wars followed by baby booms.Since the start of the th century there has been a general downward trend with some fluctuations, including a surge in births during the s economic boom. The recession that began after the   global credit crunch also affected birth rates. Separate analysis of that period across Europe found that poor economic conditions were associated with fertility declines, particularly in countries that experienced higher levels of unemployment.It is plausible that the drop in births in Scotland over the last few months was caused by the consequences of lockdowns. Despite furlough and other efforts by governments to support families, there has been a rise in unemployment, particularly among the young. Surveys show that levels of depression and anxiety have risen, and couples considering starting a family will have felt a lot of uncertainty. For those living together, being at home with their partner on a daily basis might have been an appealing prospect at first, but less so as the weeks and months of restrictions continued.Other factors might have contributed. Ante-and post-natal care has continued throughout the pandemic, but women may have been concerned about accessing health services. Some may have decided to delay a pregnancy on that basis. Access to fertility clinics and IVF reduced in the early months of the pandemic. Dating and forming new relationships was much more challenging. Maintaining intimacy between couples who live apart has been badly affected because we werenrsquot able to visit other peoplersquos households during lockdown restrictions.The economic, emotional and social upheaval that the coronavirus crisis have caused all suggest that the recent further decline in births may be the start of a real trend.But Professor Anderson urges caution. One assumption ndash that women may have delayed a pregnancy to avoid needing to access maternal health services ndash isnrsquot reflected in recent figures. He and Dr Roughsedge obtained data from Public Health Scotland for the number of women booking for antenatal care up to November . There was a small decline of between -% since May that year but nothing signicant.Migration may also play a role. Over the last year, the number of non UK-born workers resident here has fallen by more than K based on the Labour Force Survey. Migrants particularly from Europe are often employed in the sectors that have been badly affected during the pandemic. For many, especially those who have arrived recently, the choice would have been to stay here, with no job, less or no money, and pay for relatively expensive rented accommodation orhome to family. This may have affected birth rates.The number of births fluctuates between months and years and it would take a large and sustained drop to have a big impact on Scotlandrsquos long term population projections. But there are things governments can do to support people in Scotland to have children. One of the main reasons why the last recession had a less damaging impact on birth rates in the UK compared to where in Europe is because the UK government slashed interest rates in the winter of -.They fell from % in the summer of  to .% by March . This reduced mortgage payments and gave couples more confidence that they had enough funds to start a family. LINDA BAULD:Vaccines are giving us hope ndash and a cautious route out of this pandemicA study by economists at the Bank of England found that each percentage point drop in UK interest rates increased births by %, resulting in an overall increase of .% in the UK over the next three years. In Scotland births still declined ndash but to a lesser extent than the longer term trend, suggesting that these measures might have made a dference here also.As we emerge from the pandemic we need to consider the best policies to support parents, families and children. We should protect sexual, fertility and maternal health services, and take a long term view on wider policies that will decide what happens to birth rates in Scotland. Babies born now or in the next few months wonrsquot know about the pandemic until they are older. But they will play their part in our recovery.Linda Bauld is Chair of Public Health at the University of Edinburgh.

title: presenter-mccoy-leaves-bbc-18-years-join-andrew-neils-new-channel-gb-news
