A range of new temporary measures are to be introduced in a bidto improve facilities for pedestrians and increase public space in Derrys city centre. The scheme has been agreed in partnership with Derry City and Strabane District Council as part of the Covid recovery process. Measures include the introduction of a one-way system from Carlisle Road, through Ferryquay Gate into The Diamond. The existing parking area at the quadrant outside the former Austin’s department storewill be removed to create more public space. A priority system for traffic is to be introduced at Shipquay Gate which will allow a new footway to be created under this historic gate. googletag.cmd.push New spaces are also to be created on Bishop Street to facilitate outdoor trading opportunities for cafeacute-type businesses. Making the announcement, Infrastructure Minister Nicola Mallonsaid: “The Covid pandemic has brought many changes to how we conduct our daily lives and as we move towards a recovery phase I want to play my part in the transformation that our society deserves. This means creating a greener, cleaner more sustainable environment with less reliance on motor vehicles and a renewed focus on those who wish to walk, wheel and cycle. Once completed these measures will transform the Derry cityscape, providing safe spaces for all who work and live there to meet, shop and travel. googletag.cmd.push “I am also committed to working with other local councils, stakeholders and local people so that we can shape our future together and deliver similar changes across our villages, towns and cities.” Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, Cllr Brian Tierney, welcomed the introduction of the new measures saying he hoped they would facilitate the reopening of businesses once restrictions were lted and help encourage the public back into the city centre to socialise and shop in a safe environment. “These temporary interventions willredesignthis important urban space and create a more attractive and accessible town centre that will help restore customer confidence and drive footfall so we can rebuild our business, retail, tourism and hospitality sectors as they prepare to reopen.”      --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. An incident in which a pet dog was left requiring emergency surgery has been described as traumatic by the Mayor of a local council. The dog and its owner had been enjoying a walk on Benone Strand when the pet swallowed discarded fishing tackle. A hook became embedded in the animal’s throat and another lodged in the woman’s hand as she tried to remove them. Following some quick thinking to prevent any further harm, the dog is now recovering at home after going through a procedure at the vets. The Mayor of Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council Alderman Mark Fielding urged anyone fishing in public areas to leave no trace. googletag.cmd.push “We know lots of people enjoy a visit to our beaches with their families and pets and there’s an expectation that these are safe places to walk and explore, he said. I was very disappointed to hear about what happened to this dog which could have been killed due to the careless actions of others. “Any litter left in our beautul open spaces is a disgrace, but items like hooks, lines, weights and bait pose an extra risk due to the injuries they can cause to both pets, wildle and children. An x-ray showing the fishing hook lodged in the dogs throat. googletag.cmd.push “We should all adopt the ‘leave no trace’ motto and ensure that we take litter home or leave items in a bin. “If you fish along our beaches, or from boats, please ensure you collect all your belongings including waste items, and make sure they are properly disposed of. “This was a very traumatic experience for this lady and her pet, and I hope they both make a full recovery. “We need everyone to work together to ensure Causeway Coast and Glens is a safe and clean place for all, and with the approach of the brighter months when our open spaces might be even more attractive, this message has never been more important.     “Across the Borough, we’re fortunate to have many volunteer litter pickers whose actions, along with those of our own cleansing staff, help to keep our road sides and green spaces looking their very best. Their actions are an example to us all and you can support them by making sure to always dispose of your rubbish responsibly. The newly-refurbished Studio  Youth and Community Arts Centre at Skeoge in Derry was officially opened yesterday by Education Minister Peter Weir. The occasion saw the launch of a new -plus seat auditorium and multi-al space at Studio  and marked the completion of the Department of Education’s Voluntary Youth Capital Funding Scheme of  which provided capital grants across the voluntary youth sector in Northern Ireland to allow successful organisations to invest in refurbishment, extend or rebuild premises. Mr Weir said the refurbishment would benefit the young people of the Ballyarnett area. He added: “These facilities provide young people with a safe and friendly environment to develop their own inidual skills, which will in turn improve their own abilities within the local community. The education of young people can be greatly enhanced through informal learning opportunities provided by youth work. googletag.cmd.push “Voluntary Youth Capital Schemes such as the Community Arts Centre, demonstrate my commitment to enhance the delivery and performance of youth work and improve the lives of young people, in particular those most at risk and vulnerable.” Oliver Green, GSCAs artistic director, said: “Greater ShantallowCommunity Arts are delighted to celebrate our wonderful new space that the investment from the Department of Education’s Voluntary Youth Capital Scheme has allowed, but also to celebrate some of the amazing achievements of the young people from our communities over the past  years that we have had the privilege working with. “The bright new vibrant space is capable of seating - and will perfectly compliment, the theatre,rooms, dance studios, plaza, exterior garden, and cafe space that Studio  has to offer and provides signicantstep forward in GSCA’s future expansive capital plans to create the North of Irelands largest and most inclusive Community Arts Centre.” googletag.cmd.push Noirin McKinney, director ofartsdevelopment at theArtsCouncilof Northern Ireland said thanks to dedicated newartspaces, such as Studio , young people would be able to take part in a truly fantastic range ofartsactivities, workshops and classes for many years to come. “For some, these positive experiences will be their very first introduction to thearts. We very much hope that the creative skills they learn will be carried with them for the rest of their lives.” Studio Youth and Community Arts Centre is the brainchild of Greater Shantallow Community Arts, a charity arts organisation that originated in  and has gone from strength to strength being the focal point for youth work and youth arts development, not only in the Greater Shantallow area, but right across the city and the North West.      --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. The Foyle Foodbank is increasing its opening hours in a bid to help more people. The food bank has been a leline for many people during the pandemic. Volunteers at the centre have been delivering food parcels throughout the local area on a daily basis. The food bank is now extending the opening hours of its base at Springtown. The centre will be open, Monday to Friday, from am to pm for anyone in need of support. A Foyle Foodbank spokesperson said they were pleased to be able to open for longer. Northern Ireland’s Covid- vaccination programme has passed three landmarks in just one day. The total number of vaccines administered has pushed past , and sits at ,. The number of first doses provided has passed , and is now ,. And the total of second doses has moved beyond , to reach ,. Health Minister Robin Swann welcomed the continued progress. “All the immense work being done to deliver the vaccination programme is giving everyone in Northern Ireland hope and optimism for the future. “More landmarks will be reached next week when we open the SSE Arena vaccination centre and community pharmacists begin administering vaccines.” googletag.cmd.push The head of the vaccination programme Patricia Donnelly said vaccination appointments are still available – including at the SSE Arena. “For those who are eligible, the best time to book is certainly now. Before too long, we will be extending the programme to lower age groups, as supplies allow, and this will increase pressure for appointment slots.” People wanting to book a vaccination centre appointment are asked to do so onlineit all possible:https:vaccinations.covid-. hscni.net booking If online booking is not possible, then the telephone booking number is   . Those eligible also have the option of waiting for their GP to contact them to arrange their jab. googletag.cmd.push The vaccination centres are providing vaccines to: the  plus age group anyone who received a shielding letter because they are Clinically Extremely Vulnerableand anyone who is a main carer of an elderly or disabled person. GPs are providing vaccines to: the  plus age group anyone who received a shielding letter because they are Clinically Extremely Vulnerablecarers patients aged  and over who have underlying medical conditions. The latter Clinically Vulnerablegroup is expected to largely mirror those who receive the winter flu vaccine each year because of their medical conditions. CEV and CV iniduals aged  and  years of age cannot receive the vaccine being used in GP practices.     These iniduals will receive a letter from their GP and are able to book a vaccination slot at one of the vaccination centres. One County Derry town has been named in the top three places to live in Northern Ireland, according to the annual Sunday Times Best Places to Live guide. Magherafelt has been included in the regions top three, alongside Strangford Loch and outright winner, Holywood, both in County Down. Expert judges behind the Sunday Times guide assessed a number of factors in making their decision, from schools, air quality, transport and broadband speed to culture, green spaces and the high street. They looked for improving towns, villages or city centres, for attractive, well-designed homes and locations bursting with community spirit. Magherafelt was selected as a supremely practical choice for families thanks to its convenient central location, rapidly improving town centre and excellent schools. googletag.cmd.push Local grammar school Rainey Endowed, which recently won the Sunday Times School of the Decade award, was singled out for praise. Judges were also impressed by the sports facilities at Meadowbank Multi-Sports Arena and Moyola Park Golf Club, as well as the towns choice of hairdressers, beauty salons and coffee shops. Sunday Times Property Editor, Helen Davies, said this had been a good year for small towns. “This guide has never been so important. The pandemic has taught us just how much we rely on our homes, our communities and our surroundings,” she said. “With working from home now common, it’s no surprise that many of us are reassessing our priorities and thinking hard about where we really want to live. googletag.cmd.push “Our focus for this year has been community, countryside and convenience. It hasn’t been a year for big cities or small villages. “Instead it is small towns that have shone: big enough to have everything you need within walking distance and small enough for everyone to feel connected.” Local councillor Darren Totten said the announcement was no surprise to him as a Magherafelt man. The focus of the experts is on amenities, location, educational and sporting facilities - which this study rightly shows to be amongst the very best available, he said. For me, though, the very best of Magherafelt is that we have a great community in the town and main ingredient in any community is the people.     The people of Magherafelt have proven many times in recent years that when anyone is in need, its all hands to the pump regardless of who it is needs help.”  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A Derry primary school has created a new Sunshine Corridor for its pupils. Model Primary School says the corridor had proved a huge hit with pupils. The corridor is made up of several colourful artworks, including one about the solar system. As well as learning, some of the artwork gives the pupils to have a bit of fun while they make their way around the school. A Derry teenager campaigning for a detox centre in the city has met with the chief executive of the Western Trust to discuss her aims. Tamzin Whites mother, Louise, died earlier this year as a result of alochol addiction at the age of only . Other members of Tamzins family have also died from addiction. In honour of them, eighteen-year-old Tamzin has launched a campaign for the creation of a local detox centre to help those fighting addictions. Yesterday, she met Western Trust chief executive, Doctor Anne Killgallen, and another senior Trust representatives. Tamzin was accompanied at the meeting by Sinn Fein Foyle MLA Karen Mullan and Emmet Doyle, an Aontu councillor on Derry City and Strabane District Council. googletag.cmd.push Speaking after the meeting, Ms Mullan said the members of the Trusts management team listened to Tamzins requests and her mums experience accessing addiction services, and their experience overall as a family. “They have agreed to look at the experience of Tamzin’s mum and will follow up to inform the wider community on services available. “Derry needs more than what we currently have when it comes to detox and addiction services. “I have every confidence that Tamzin will help improve the current situation, and I will be helping and supporting her in whatever way I can, every step of the way.” googletag.cmd.push  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Young rugby superfan and YouTube sensation, Tafu Ha’ungagot the surprise of his le winning a Zoom call with Ireland and Munster winger Keith Earls. It was part of Specsavers Something to Smile about campaign and Tafu, who regularly watches his mum play for City of Derry rugby club, was one of four lucky rugby fans across the island of Ireland who got to virtually meet an Ireland rugby hero. Specsavers are the official opticians and audiologists for the IRFU and to mark this year’s Guinness Six Nations they asked parents and grandparents to nominate their young rugby mad fans to be in with a chance of winning a surprise one-to-one video call from Keith Earls, Jordan Larmour or Garry Ringrose. googletag.cmd.push Tafu, whose family live in Coleraine, was nominated by mum Joanna and dad Tane and after his chat with Keith about all things rugby, Tafu decided to dedicate an episode of his very own YouTube channel ‘Tackling with Tafu’ to his sporting hero Keith. Tafu created Episode  ahead of the Ireland V England game and after the match said: It was an amazing game. Keith Earls’ try was brilliant and I think he got some advice from Tackling with Tafu. Tafu was thrilled when he realised that Keith had watched his previous YouTube videos and he definitely wants to continue making more episodes and is really looking forward to going back to playing mini-rugby at Ballymoney RFC along with younger brother Lotu. googletag.cmd.push As well as chatting about the Six Nations, Tafu asked Keith what his favourite game of all time was and Tafu wasn’t surprised when Keith answered, Beating New Zealand in ’, one of Ireland’s most famous games. As well as being an Ireland superfan, Tafu is an avid supporter of his mum Joanna and her teammates at City of Derry Women and he’s keen to get back to watching the ladies play when grass roots sport gets back on track. Mum Joanna said: We’re a rugby mad family and love being involved at club level as well as following the international games.     My husband Tane played rugby professionally but has retired due to injury and now enjoys being involved with our respective clubs and following the boys’ mini-rugby teams. Specsavers optometry director Judith Ball congratulated Tafu on winning such a special Zoom meeting. It was brilliant to be able to celebrate our IRFU partnership and put a smile on young rugby fans’ faces like Tafu and giving them a rare opportunity to speak to their sporting heroes. The Specsavers ‘Something to Smile About’ campaign celebrates the positivity and delight that a simple smile can bring and this story is an example of just that. title: ‘Horrible vibrations’ from street work
story: AN Ardglass resident has criticised Openreach for the ldquohorrible vibrations he experienced as the company lays new broadband fibre cable in the village.Adam Clford said he felt vibrations in his house at Bayview Drive while the companyrsquos contractors worked in the street outside.Mr Clford said: ldquoIt went on all day. It was extremely disturbing. There were very unpleasant low vibrations felt through the floor and transmitting up through the chair I was sitting on.ldquoIt was unpleasant because we felt like they were damaging the house and we had no control over it.Mr Clford said the vibrations were made worse due to the floating concrete foundations of his house.He believes Openreach should have surveyed the street before work started and used a smaller track digging machine to limit the vibrations.He also claims he was treated ldquowith contempt when he broached his concerns to a contractor.Openreach has apologised to Mr Clford, but points that the work to lay the full fibre broadband, which should be finished in a monthrsquos time, will bring major bring major benefits to , properties in the Ardglass area.ldquoWe apologise to Mr Clford and the residents who have experienced disruption and inconvenience, a spokesperson said.ldquoWe also wish to thank residents for their patience while this work has been taking place.ldquoWersquove introduced new techniques to minimise disruption and avoid digging where possible.ldquoHowever, in order to complete parts of the new network in Ardglass we have had to add additional ducting, which has required civil engineering work.ldquoThe new network will be commissioned within the next month and residents will be able to contact their communication provider to connect to faster full fibre broadband.The spokesperson said the work in Ardglass was part of a major infrastructure investment by Openreach bringing next generation broadband across Northern Ireland.ldquoFull Fibre broadband means that each property can connect directly to the exchange with a fibre optic cable, the spokesperson continued.ldquoThe new network will have a dramatic and positive impact on both broadband speeds and reliability, which is welcomed by householders and businesses demanding increased broadband speeds as a result of home schooling, working from home, and adapting to the impact of coronavirus on our daily lives..prettyPhoto

title: A very different St Patrick’s Day
story: IT was a very dferent St Patrickrsquos Day service at Down Cathedral last week.Instead of a normally packed cathedral for the annual cross-community service, there were just a few clergymen including Bishop David McClay and the Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull.Both men also took part in the wreath-laying ceremony at the patron saintrsquos final resting place in the adjoining graveyard.In addition to the cathedral service which was streamed online, a number of other events to celebrate St Patrickrsquos Day took place over the internet, including a popular prayer pilgrimage.Children and families were able to celebrate at home or locally with a specially commissioned lsquomuddy prayer trailrsquo based on words from St Patrickrsquos Breastplate.St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations normally attracts visitors from across the globe with then dayrsquos activities beginning with a service at Saul mdash the site of Patrickrsquos first church.This was not possible this year due to Covid restrictions. Bishop McClay and Dean Hull celebrated a simple service of Holy Communion before walking prayerfully from Saul to the Cathedral.Meanwhile, pilgrims at home were invited to take a virtual prayer pilgrimage with Glynis Matchett with a short film premiered on social media.The pilgrimage is inspired by Patrickrsquos journey from slave to missionary and reflects on his faith and passion for the gospel.At noon Dean Hull welcomed viewers to a live broadcast from Down Cathedral, with the Bishop leading the service.The guest speakers included Patrick Regan and singerndashsongwriter and Andy Flannagan who also joined in via video.Conscious that the past year has seen many thousands of people face traumatic situations and signicant mental health issues, the diocese had chosen the theme lsquoWhen Faith Gets Shakenrsquo for the service.Patrick Regan is the author of a book by the same name and founder and chief executive of mental health charity Kintsugi Hope which aims to create safe and supportive spaces for those struggling with emotional and mental health challenges.He is also the founder of urban youth work charity XLP and the author of five books. Patrick has travelled widely working with and on behalf of the poorest communities and is a regular contributor on radio and television on issues of poverty and justice.Andy Flannagan is a Lutonndashbased, Irish singerndashsongwriter who was previously a hospital doctor.His campaigning song writing drew him into the political arena, and he is Executive Director of Christians in Politics. One of his driving passions is to see a just rewiring of the global economic system.Drawing on their own experiences, Patrick and Andy encouraged people to be honest with God in lament and to trust that he brings beauty from their brokenness.Andy sang two pieces ndash Fragile and a song of complaint based on Psalm , while soloist, Ruth Thompson, sang two songs ndash What Grace is Mine and Christ Be Beside Me ndash accompanied by Cathedral organist Michael McCracken.Following the service, clergy gathered at St Patrickrsquos grave for a socially distanced wreath laying ceremony.And in keeping with the focus on mental wellbeing, the wreath was laid by Mr Jackie Breen, a senior mental health nurse based at Finneston House in Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Chief denies Finneston House closure claims
story: THE districtrsquos most senior health chief has categorically dismissed rumours that a key facility based in Downpatrick is to close at the weekend.Finneston House mdash run by the South Eastern Trust mdash is based at the Ardglass Road on the outskirts of the town and provides an acute mental health community service.Last week, a number of councillors posted on social media that they had been made aware of reports that the facility, which has a long history as a base for mental health services, was to close at weekends with services moved to Belfast.Dispelling the rumours during a special briefing with local politicians on Monday afternoon, Mr Seamus McGoran said there were ldquoabsolutely no plans to close Finneston House which, he said, was line for a pound, investment to support the continued delivery of mental health and other community services.Mr McGoran, acting chief executive of the South Eastern Trust, said he was more than happy to set the record on the future of the mental health facility.ldquoThere are absolutely no plans at all to remove the weekend mental health service from Finneston House and relocate to Belfast, he declared.He said he was ldquosomewhat irked that some councillors had chosen to put out a statement on social media last week saying that he had received ldquodisturbing reports that the health trust was going to transfer the service.ldquoThis is absolutely not true and I would preferany of you [councillors] have issues or concerns that you would ask the Trust about them, continued Mr McGoran.ldquoWhat happens is your hear rumours and treat them as fact and start making statements on the back of that. We have an obligation to communicate responsibly with the public and we have an obligation not to create anxiety with the very people who need to access our mental health services.ldquoFinneston House will continue to be there andthere is more demand for the service it provides we will put more resources into it. That will be how we deliver the service, he said.ldquoI donrsquot know where these rumours came from and I would make a plea to please talk to us before starting putting stuff on social media. Thatrsquos how we get a constructive relationship.Mr McGoran added: ldquoWhen councillors start to put messages out asthey are factual it does not do the people we serve any good. In fact, it creates anxiety where there is no need.Confirming the planned pound, investment at Finneston House, Mrs Roisin Coulter, the health trustrsquos director of planning and performance, said that a decade ago there were plans to dispose of the facility.She said that since then, services provided there had grown and it now played an important role..prettyPhoto

title: East Down community rejects plans%2C claims PFA
story: THE Downpatrick and East Down community rejects plans to merge three local post-primary schools together, a parentsrsquo opposition group has claimed.The Red High Parents and Friends Associationndash the parent body of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School ndash has made an th hour call on the Education Minister to leave the school as it is and instead merge St Maryrsquos High School and De La Salle High School.The call comes as the public consultation process ends on Monday into the proposed closure of all schools by September next year and the creation of a new voluntary grammar school comprising of all three schools.Red High PFA spokesperson Cormac Artt has been at the front of the parentsrsquo opposition to any merger of the grammar school over the last few years.He said that the association remained ldquosteadfast in its opposition to the development proposal agreed by each schoolrsquos trustees, the De La Salle Congregation, and the Education Authority.Mr Artt stressed the local opposition to the amalgamation of the three schools remained strong.ldquoOver this past two months, our volunteer parentsrsquo group has canvassed opinion and debate from across the locality to ensure all voices are heard in response to this proposal, he said.ldquoHundreds of parents have been in touch and it is evident the biggest shake-up in post primary education in this area for a generation has ignited our communityrsquos collective agreement this proposal falls at so many hurdles.ldquoJudging by the sheer number of contacts our parentsrsquo group has had to answer, this community firmly rejects this proposal and calls on the Minister for Education to do the right thing and scrap it.He said his group had engaged with local politicians who now fully understand the impact of development proposal and said that they had cross-party support ldquowith only a minority ignoring the facts or refusing to engage directly with parents.He continued: ldquoAs a representative parent group for St Patrickrsquos Grammar School, we fully support our Board of Governorsrsquo statement and that of our school management team. The closure of a fully sustainable school does not make any sense whatsoever and our friends at both St Maryrsquos and the De La Salle recognise this also.ldquoThis is a town plan, not an area plan as the proposal purports to be, and does not surprisingly address post primary schools in Crossgar or Ballynahinch, a move, we would suggest, to a future proposal for those schools.ldquoBut more importantly, the inequality this will create across a raft of issues, from admissions, transport, gender equality, SEN and rural needs, renders this proposal nothing less than detrimental to education in this area.ldquoWe call on the Minister for Education to retain St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in its current form and amalgamate St Maryrsquos and De La Salle Schools..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 28%2C 2001
story: NEWCASTLE ndash A major review into the future of primary education provision in the greater Newcastle area could lead to the merger of up to three local schools.A review into the primary controlled sector, involving Castlewellan, Newcastle, Clough and Dundrumrsquos Downshire Primary Schools, has been launched by the South Eastern Education and Library Board.Although the investigation will not be complete until next year, principals at the smaller schools have been informed that amalgamation at a brand new green field site is a possibility.Central to the Boardrsquos thinking is continuing decline in enrolment at Downshire and the urgent need to replace Clough primary which is working to full capacity. It is understood the Board is leaning towards a merger of these two schools.DOWNPATRICK ndash A major stumbling block to the development of a new cinema in Downpatrick has been removed.Dunleath Estates has given permission for part of Dunleath Park to be redeveloped as a cinema complex, ending months of speculation about the future of the ambitious project.Proposals for the multi-screen cinema at Dunleath Park have faced delays over the past  months as the Down Council awaited legal clearance from Dunleath Estates.But at Mondayrsquos meeting of the councilrsquos Client Services Committee, it was revealed that representatives from the estate have agreed to all the land to be used for the complex, subject to restrictions.This means Dunleath Estates will remove a restrictive covenant which species that the area can only be used for recreational and leisure purposes.KILLYLEAGH ndash British Legion officials in Killyleagh have expressed concern that funding they were promised to provide a new War Memorial in the town will not be made available.Officials claim they received a letter from Down Council indicating it would ensure pound, was included in its capital programme for the new financial year, paving the way for the memorial to be provided at the top of High Street.However, Legion officials say the money has not been included in the local authority budget and are ldquodeeply disappointed at its decision, but they hope the cash will be made available next year to help them relocate the memorial, which is currently located at the side of Killyleagh Castle.Down Council has already agreed to provide the Legion with a plot of land to house the new structure, but has confirmed it cannot give a guarantee at this stage that that pound, Legion officials require will be made available.SAINTFIELD ndash All-day parkers in Saintfield have been asked to be more considerate to the townrsquos traders.The call came last Wednesday night when all day parkers were urged by Saintfield Town Committee not tothe town to what was once a major problem.Locals who attended the annual meeting, in Saintfield library, claimed that as result of people parking in Main Street for several hours each week day, traders were losing out on valuable business.Speaking after the meeting, which was also attended by local councillors William Dick and Robert Burgess, the committeersquos newly elected chairman, Mr Sam Spratt, said parking in the town had ldquogreatly improved in recent years, but warned that motorists were starting to ldquoslip back into old habits.CROSSGAR ndash The Department of Regional Development is to be asked to carry out repairs to what has been described as one of the worst roads in the Province.Down councillors have backed moves calling on the Department to have repair work carried out at the Killyleagh Road outside Crossgar which was dug up recently to allow the laying of a new sewer pipe.The work was part of a poundm scheme to allow the pumping of sewage from Crossgar for treatment in Killyleagh. But the quality of the road repairs has been called in to question by local residents and Rowallance councillor Miss Margaret Ritchie.She first raised the problem on the eve of a major report published recently by the Northern Ireland Audit Office into road openings by ious utilities, including the Water Service, Roads Service, British Telecom and ious gas companies.SEAFORDE ndash A planning decision refusing to allow the replacement of derelict buildings in Seaforde with a new housing development,has been deferred by Down Council.Councillors and Planning Service officials are to hold an office meeting to discuss the plan to demolish premises at Main Street and replace them with seven townhouses and four apartments.Planners had initially ruled that no ldquoexceptional reason had been given to justy the demolition and suggested thatallowed to proceed, the new development would be out of keeping with the general charter of existing premises in Seaforde.Planners also claimed the scheme would be contrary to rural landing policy and thatpermitted, the design, layout and landscaping of the scheme would be unacceptable.They also ruled the development would harm he privacy of adjoining residents.The building was originally listed, but it was confirmed at last weekrsquos monthly council meeting that it has since been delisted.DOWNPATRICK ndash Talks seeking a new base for Downpatrickrsquos weekly market are set to take place tomorrow morning, but stallholders are angry they have not been invited.Traders are outraged they have been excluded from the meeting between Down Council officials, the Department of the Environment and the Down Lisburn Trust, who all own part of the Lower Market Street car park where the Saturday market is currently held.It is understood the meeting is to discuss whether the weekly market can retain its current site, or have to move to free up vital spaces for visitors to the new St Patrick Centre.Traders have become increasingly hostile towards the council, claiming news of the decisions were a complete surprise as the council recently told them the market was not going to be moved.The current mood among stallholders is one of confusion and anger at the councilrsquos apparent disinterest in their welfare.ARDGLASS ndash As tougher restrictions are introduced by the European Commission in an effort to rejuvenate depleted fish stocks, one local skipper has warned that the industry is at rock bottom.Speaking just hours before the government introduced legislation banning fishing on vast stretches of local waters until April , Ardglass fisherman Paul Wills said things could not get any worse.The ban introduced at midnight on Friday was expected to be further extended yesterday during a special meeting at Stormont when the government was due to discuss a tie-up of all vessels as part of the overall cod recovery programme.Although the Ardglass industry is prawn-based, Mr Wills said local fishermen rely on their by-catch of white fish at the time of the year and said the economic consequences of the current restriction were great.Mr Wills, who skippers his own vessel, said he earns half today what he would have earned  years ago.CROSSGAR ndash The birth of the Free Presbyterian Church in Crossgar  years ago was celebrated in the village last week.The highlight of the week-long series of events to mark the churchrsquos golden anniversary came last Thursday night with a special service conducted by the Rev Fred Greenfield and the Moderator of the Free Presbyterian Church, Dr Ian Paisley.The church was pack to capacity for the service which took place a few days before Free Presbyterians from across the globe gathered for an anniversary service at Belfastrsquos Odyssey arena.The Crossgar service was an emotional one for some members of the congregation who joined the church after it was formed by Dr Paisley and a number of local men..prettyPhoto

title: Golf clubs welcome new sustainability funding
story: LOCAL golf clubs are to share in a pound.m support package for the sport province-wide.A total of  clubs throughout Northern Ireland will share in the funding package announced by Sport NI.The biggest share will go to Royal County Down in Newcastle, which has been awarded pound,,.The next highest local award goes to Ardglass Golf Club, which will receive pound,.Spa are next with pound,, while St Patrickrsquos, Downpatrick, are set to receive pound,.The money comes as part of the Northern Ireland Sports Sustainability Fund, which aims to help stabilise areas of the sports sector that have been most effected by Covid-.Chief Executive of Golf Ireland, Mark Kennelly said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic continues to have a severe financial impact on golf clubs which, despite being closed for long periods over the last  months, have signicant costs to bear in maintaining facilities and the courses themselves.ldquoGolf Ireland is committed to supporting its affiliated clubs in every way we can, and we are delighted that this funding has been secured for clubs in Northern Ireland.Another local beneficiary from the Sports Sustainability Fund is the Downpatrick-based Lecale Swimming Club, which is to receive funding of pound,..prettyPhoto

title: Italian job for Conor
story: DOWNPATRICK goalkeeper Conor Hazard has been included in the Northern Ireland squad for their opening World Cup qualying game against Italy tomorrow night.The  year-old Celtic custodian is one of four keepers in the squad and is almost likely to lose out to Bailey Peacock-Farrell for a starting berth against the vaunted Italians, who are on home soil in Parma.Hazard is also in the squad for the next qualier against Bulgaria in Belfast next Wednesday night and may see some action in a friendly against the United States on Sunday.Northern Ireland manager Ian Baraclough had admired Hazard for a long time and knows what Hazard is capable of.Baraclough was formerly manager of the Northern Ireland U-  side and made Hazard team captain.Itrsquos been quite a time for Hazard, whose career had gone from strength to strength in the last few months.Hazard made his first team debut for Celtic against Lille in December as the Hoops won - in the Europa League. He kept a clean sheet against Kilmarnock a few days later and a string of good performances resulted in him being picked for the Scottish Cup final against Hearts.It was a fairytale match for the Downpatrick man as he saved two spot kicks in a penalty shoot-out to seal a historic fourth consecutive treble for Neil Lennonrsquos side.His exploits were rewarded when he signed a new two-year contract with the Parkhead club a few weeks ago.Hazard has made seven appearances for Celtic this season, his last coming in a - draw with Livingston in January.He said: Just playing seven games altogether this season has given me a great boost in my confidence. I go into training every day knowing there is an opportunity to get in the team and go and perform and get a few wins.Hazard made his international debut for Northern Ireland against Costa Rica in a friendly fixture in  during a tour of Central America. His manager at the time was Michael OrsquoNeill, who now manages Stoke City in the English Championship.Northern Ireland couldnrsquot have had a harder opening fixture in their World Cup campaign. The Italians are renewed for being tough opponents and will be expecting to see off the green and white army.Killyleaghrsquos Trevor Carson misses out on a place in the Northern Ireland squad due to a knee injury that he sustained last December after landing awkwardly whilst playing against Kilmarnock.Itrsquos the latest in a series of injuries which have beset the Motherwell keeper in the past few years, starting with deep vein thrombosis in , followed by a meniscus tear earlier this season.Carsonrsquos latest injury has ruled him out for the rest of this yearrsquos campaign..prettyPhoto

title: Locals triumph in Kiwi competition
story: TWO local camogie players have been celebrating success in New Zealand.Dearbhla Arkins, from Castlewellan, and Amy Doyle, from Drumaroad, were victorious in New Zealandrsquos senior camogie championship.The duo were part of the Canterbury side, who were eventually crowned champions after defeating Auckland in the final in Christchurch.The championship was the biggest GAA tournament in the world at that time due to the pandemic and hosted  teams and over  players from across New Zealand.The pandemic resulted in last yearrsquos competition in Auckland to be cancelled, so for the championship to be given the go-ahead was a big boost to the locals, who have a strong affiliation with Irish sports.Amyand Dearbhlajoined Canterbury at the tail end of the season, just in time for the championship.Dearbhlarsquos father, Vincent, who is vice-chairman of St Johnrsquos GAC, congratulated both women on their trophy win.ldquoThe ladies did brilliantly winning the cup, and itrsquos good to see them representing their team so well, he said.ldquoI am very proud of Dearbhla. She has always been very involved with St Johnrsquos, competing in football since primary school and recently playing for the senior ladiesrsquo football team.ldquoShe has taken part in numerous fundraisers such as the clubrsquos Strictly ComeDancing and other charity events. She has been a great asset and club representative.ldquoItrsquos great to see her carry her love for the GAA across to the other side of the world.Dearbhla has spent the last two years in New Zealand and plans to stay for at least another year mdash in the hope of another trophy triumph..prettyPhoto

title: MP presses Minister on starting date for bypass
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has been asked to confirm a start date for work on Ballynahinchrsquos eagerly-awaited multi-million pound bypass.The appeal has been issued by South Down MP Chris Hazzard who was previously a minister in charge at the Department for Infrastructure.He has criticised Mrs Mallon for ldquostallingrsquo on the bypass linking the Newcastle and Saintfield roads after what he described as ldquoyet another disappointing response from the Minister in response to his calls for action on the long awaited scheme.Mr Hazzard recently asked the roads minister to publicly commit to a start date on the project following years of preparatory work being successfully complete. He said she declined.ldquoThis scheme has been shovel ready for some time, the MP continued.ldquoIndeed, all the geotechnical surveys, public consultations and the legal stages have been complete and in order many months ago. Yet the Minister refuses to sign-off on a commencement order.ldquoThe failure to even provide a detailed, logical explanation as to why she has not yet signed off on this scheme has created a growing fear in the local community that she is inexplicably stalling on this eagerly awaited project.The MP said that once again last weekend Ballynahinch suffered chronic congestion, with cars queued for miles to get through the town on Sunday evening as people ed home from visiting the area.Mr Hazzard warned that this will be a scene repeated each and every weekend and in the opposite direction each weeknight as commutershome from work outside Ballynahinch when Covid- restrictions ease again in the time ahead.Slieve Croob councillor Cathy Mason, who is also calling for a start date for the bypass, said the ldquotimely delivery of the long overdue roads scheme would be a great boost for both the local economy and the wellbeing of the community.She added: ldquoThe Minister must bring this issue to a speedy conclusion as soon as possible, sign the commencement order and announce a date for construction to commence. Nothing less will be acceptable to the local community.A Department for Infrastructure spokeswoman said Mrs Mallon previously announced her commitment to fund the continued development of a number of strategic road improvement schemes delayed by the collapse of the Assembly for three years.She said these included the Ballynahinch bypass as part of a plan to aid economic recovery and community transformation, while addressing regional imbalance.ldquoThe Ballynahinch bypass scheme is now at an advanced stage of development and a review of the environmental reports has also been completed. The Minister intends to provide a further update on the scheme shortly, said the spokesperson.ldquoThe Minister is committed to moving ahead with the Ballynahinch bypass scheme.Major progress has been made over recent years to advance the scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads with the bypass designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the bypass where the major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.The bypass, which is expected to take  months to construct, is the single biggest road scheme ever proposed for the district, with roads officials insisting that the scheme will reduce journey times and improve road safety..prettyPhoto

title: Quoile access set to be upgraded for anglers
story: CONCERN about access to the Quoile River in Downpatrick for disabled anglers is to be addressed by a leading government department.The Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairshas confirmed that the Environment Agency is to be asked to approve the possible installation of disabled angling stands beside the two designated disabled parking bays at a redeveloped car park beside the riverrsquos floodgates.The Department mdash which has also agreed to meet with local anglers mdash saidthe new stands are provided, they will reduce the need for those with mobility issues to have to make their way to an existing stand around a quarter of a mile from the car park.Anglers have expressed concern that a new barrier erected on a wall which separates the car park from the waterway now prevents disabled anglers from fishing at this location.They say it is over a year since they were informed that new stands for those with mobility issues was being discussed by civil servants, calling for their immediate implementation.DAERA insists that the riverside car park was never designated either as a specic angling area or one for the use of disabled fishermen, conceding that local anglers disagree with this point which is why a meeting with them to discuss the issue is necessary.In a letter to anglers, the Department confirms that neither they nor Disability NI were consulted about the work at the car park as it would not restrict or remove disabled angling facilities. Itrsquos a point that anglers disagree with.DERA explained the work on the banks of the river created two dedicated disabled parking spaces in the car park where previously there had been none.ldquoThere was no legal requirement to consult on the proposed improvement works and therefore the consultation undertaken went beyond what was required, to specically noty as well as seek comment and feedback from site users, said a departmental official.He also confirmed that notice of DAERArsquos intention to carry out improvement work was clearly displayed at the Quoile site in advance of it being undertaken.The official also confirmed that consultation on the car park investment was initiated with Newry, Mourne and Down Council and a number of local councillors who were contacted by telephone about the proposed investment.DAERA confirmed that regular tree inspections are carried out at the Quoile River and that after storms, areas of the Quoile Nature Reserve are checked by staff for fallen trees and branches that may have come down.In addition, it says this area is subject to regular visual inspections by staff and where any concerns are identied, advice will be sought from qualied tree surgeons or arboriculturists any necessary work carried out.In his letter to anglers, the DAERA official said he appreciates that it was not satisfactory for disabled anglers to make their way to access current angling facilities a quarter of a mile from the car park, confirming plans for two new educated stands to meet the needs of those with mobility problems.A spokesman for Downpatrick anglers said they have never suggested that there was a dedicated disabled fishing stand at the car park before it was redeveloped. He said fishermen could fish in the river at the car park from their wheelchairs as there was a small wall in place.ldquoSince the car park was redeveloped, a barrier has been attached to the wall which now makes it impossible for disabled anglers to fish from this location. As a result, they have to make their way, along with all their gear, to another stand which is a quarter of a mile away, he said.ldquoThis is highly unsatisfactory. Would it be proper to tell someone with mobility issues who stops in a car park to be told that the shopping centre, GP surgery or disabled toilet that they needed to visit was half a mile away  I suspect not.The spokesman added local anglers have been told about plans for disabled fishing stands at the car park for some time now and that the Environment Agency is being asked for its view.ldquoWhat we want to see is delivery for disabled anglers. They have rights which must be recognised, he said.The spokesman added: ldquoWe remain in the eye of a pandemic and mental health is a major issue for many health professionals who are concerned about the fall-out from the impact of the coronavirus. Fishing is very therapeutic and we would strongly argue that the provision of new disabled angling stands on the banks of the Quoile should be a priority and will be of tremendous benefit.Anglers have also expressed concern that the redeveloped car park on the banks of the river has become a magnet for anti-social behaviour are are thankful that no one was injured when a large branch fell to the ground several weeks ago. They insist that the anti-social behaviour problems cannot go left unchecked..prettyPhoto

title: Renowned chef Paul makes return on Great British Menu
story: DUNDRUM chef Paul Cunningham will once again be tempting judges with his tantalising creations when the Great British Menu makes a welcomethis evening.The hugely popular series airs on BBC Two every Wednesday, Thursday and Friday over the next eight weeks with Paul and other chefs from across the UK serving up food heaven.The Great British Menu mdash now in its th season mdash will not be a new experience for Paul as he has already appeared before.He is one of four Northern Ireland chefs taking part in the prestigious competition which concludes with the famous banquet. Among those from the province joining him is Carryduffrsquos Gemma Austin.Paul, who is delighted to be selected again, is head chef and director of Brunelrsquos in Newcastle and has a close link with the South Eastern Regional Collegersquos hospitality and catering programmes.And when the popular BBC programme concludes, Paul will be making an appearance at the collegersquos Downpatrick campus to showcase some of his creations when the show is finished.Self-taught Paul said the main inspiration behind his passion for fresh, seasonal produce is his grandfather who would often take him foraging along the Dundrum coastline.He said local ingredients are very important to him and intends to transport some of his foraging expertise to the Great British Menu.The theme of this yearrsquos hit television show is British invention as  marks the th anniversary of Sir Tim Berners-Lee making the internet widely available to the masses, while Helen Sharman became the first British astronaut to go into space.Some of Paulrsquos dishes have been inspired by Northern Ireland pioneers who have made their mark on the globe, including Frank Partridge who invented the defibrillator and Harry Ferguson.Not surprisingly, one of Paulrsquos other influences is Victorian engineer Isambard Kingdom Brunel, who his Newcastle restaurant is named after.While the first in the new series airs tonight, the Great British Menu was filmed last year, with Covid regulations in place, with all the chefs spaced out across the kitchen.Paul Mercer, deputy head of hospitality and catering at the South Eastern Regional College, said shows like the Great British Menu inspire people, whether it is to try something new, have a go at making something dferent, or aspire to a career in the hospitality and catering industry.ldquoTo say the past year has been a challenge, is an understatement, he said. ldquoBut we have seen restaurants and chefs turn their businesses on their heads to keep going.ldquoAt the same time, we have had to get really creative at the College to ensure our students continue to learn and pick up the skills they need, to be part of the industry when it opens up again.ldquoWe are all getting ready and the Great British Menu will certainly whet our appetites for when that happens.Mr Mercer added: ldquoWe wish Paul, Gemma and the other Northern Ireland contestants, all the very best for the forthcoming season of the Great British Menu. We know they will do us all proud..prettyPhoto

title: Schools reopen their doors to students
story: POST primary schools welcomed back Years - students after over nine weeks of remote learning following the the Christmas lockdown.For the students it was the first time they had to got see their teachers and peers face to face in what is the most important time of the school year ndash the run-up to their examinations.It is hoped that students from Year  to Year  willto full-time classes at school after the Easter break.The students were supported with their remote learning by teachers with Zoom teaching sessions and course packs.However, all principals and teachers agreed this week that nothing can compare with education in the classroom situation.Mr Joe McCann, principal of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, said that Monday provided an opportunity for students to reconnect with friends.ldquoThroughout lockdown we were keen to establish clear boundaries for our students with mental health and well-being to the fore, he said.ldquoBy establishing a routine where students were engaged in their learning between :am and :pm, we were telling our students that while we expected them to work hard during school hours, we also expected them to make time for themselves and their families each afternoon and evening.ldquoIn preparation for  students ing to school today, as a staff, our aim was to alleviate any of the anxieties students are experiencing about ing to school and how grades will be determined.Mrs Maud Perry, principal of Down High School, said that the school had been a very dferent place without the normal buzz of conversation and ldquothe dynamic that exists in classrooms.She said: ldquoOur pupils will be pleased toto school for a range of reasons. Of course, they will enjoy learning in classrooms and laboratories with their teachers, but they will also be happy to see their friends and re-establish the structure that school provides.Mrs Perry said the school had taken steps once again taken to ensure that the safety of pupils and staff is paramount and there was mandatory wearing of face coverings throughout the school.Mr Ciaran Maguire, principal of De La Salle High School in Downpatrick, said theof students meant a ldquo to normality.ldquoOur students worked diligently and enthusiastically during the lockdown, using the blended learning approach, he added. ldquoThe hard work of our teachers and parents during this current lockdown allowed for the continuation of quality teaching and learning. However, all would agree that there is no substitute for classroom based education and all the positive interpersonal relationships, and well-being assurances that come with it.Ms Rosemary McLaughlin, principal of St Maryrsquos High School in Downpatrick, also agreed there was a discernible ldquobuzz in the air on Monday.ldquoIn the morning students had the chance to catch up with their friends and teachers over breakfast, she said. ldquoStudents and teachers were eager to get back into their classrooms and enjoyed the face to face teaching. There was a productive buzz and an enthusiastic and warm atmosphere around the school.Blackwater Integrated College in Downpatrick was also happy to welcome back their Year  students.The principal, Mr Stephen Taylor, said: ldquoIt was a very relaxed start for students to allow them to catch up with friends and staff they had not seen for a long time.ldquoLots of preparation work was carried out before students ed to allow them to be able to access all classes safely and staff all participated in getting the college ready for their . We have pastoral support available for students with our newly appointed youth worker and teaching staff are all very conscious to keep the demands on students manageable as we work towards getting Centre determined grades compiled for all students.Mr Stephen Hanna, principal of St Colmcillersquos High School in Crossgar, said that schools were nothing without students who brought the buildings ldquoto le.Speaking of the co-operation between the school and parents and the preparations of theof students, Mr Hanna said: ldquoWe have kept in constant communication with parents to be as supportive as we possibly can in meeting the everyday challenges faced by so many at present.ldquoThis week in our re-start, we are concentrating on getting our pupils back into regular routines and supporting their positiveto school. Pupil good mental health and wellbeing is at the forefront of our efforts and we will be doing everything that we can to be that support to our pupils they need.He added that departments across the school are focused on gathering the evidence required by the examination authorities to ensure that all our pupils achieve the grades which they so rightly deserve.Miss Sarah-Lucy Hynds, principal of Saintfield High School, spoke that her ing Year  students were ldquoa positive affirmation of all that we do ndash their resilience, strength and determination are inspiring.She stressed that work to support Years - students at home was still on-going.ldquoWe take great pride in the fact that the schoolrsquos Resilience Curriculum has continued to be rolled out online, utilising external agencies to assist our boys and girls in these challenging times, and to support their well-being, she said.ldquoThe school also appointed a Blended Learning Co-ordinator in Term  of this year, which has been an extremely successful strategy to help children engage with their online work, and to provide guidance and advice for parents and carers.The principal of Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch, Mr Peter Dobbin, said the school was delighted to welcome back its students.He added: ldquoLockdown has been hard on everyone and even though schools are now excelling in their delivery of online teaching, educators need the face to face exposure to really connect, reach out and support our young people at this time.ldquoEducation is much more than just delivering subject content, it is about enabling our young people to reach their full potential and become lsquoFully Aliversquo.Mr Mark Morgan, principal of St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College, also in Ballynahinch, said: ldquoWhile remote learning continues for those students in Year -, these senior exam students will be completing their studies in class. The school is very proud of the resilience, and positive engagement shown by students in meeting the challenges of this academic year.Ms Clare Murnin, Head of School Productions of St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan, said that staff and students alike were delighted to be back in the classroom,She said: ldquoWe have been engaging in remote learning since January  via ious online s. Whilst this has proved to be a valuable learning tool at this time, students and teachers alike certainly appreciate the invaluable teaching that takes place face to face.ldquo Students have also enjoyed the social aspects of being back at school and there was certainly a lot of happy faces on Monday when students met up with their friends once again, albeit behind masks.Mr Kevin Lambe, principal of Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle, said: ldquoWe are very much looking forward to seeing our younger students too, but are glad that theto school has been phased so that we have this week to reassure and support our GCSE and A-Level students and to re-establish our Covid safety measures before a full .ldquoMany students are coming back confident and refreshed, and we are also aware that some students have faced additional challenges, Wi-Fi challenges, family pressures, and emotional challenges. ldquoMr James Hay, principal of St Columbarsquos College in Portaferry, said: ldquoWe are delighted to see them all back to school and commend all pupils, families and staff for all of their efforts with online learning.ldquoThese Year  pupils have impressed us with their resilience, dedication and enthusiasm for learning despite missing school from March ndash June  and January ndash March . They deserve every success and support as they prepare for the next stage of their education..prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde home to feature on RTE TV show
story: A FORMER schoolhouse which used to be part of the Seaforde estate was featured in RTErsquos prestigious Home of the Year programme last night.Owned by interior designer Richard Rodgers and his mother Noleen, the four-bedroom home is a stunningmixture of tradition and modernity which blends effortlessly ndash thanks to Richardrsquos eye for design.Itrsquos one of  homes vying for this yearrsquos honour with only two representing the north in what has become a must watch show since it began.Richard, who is responsible for many of the IKEA room designs we see in stores, explained that the renovated and extended house has a story all of its own to tell.ldquoIt dates back to the th century and was part of the original estate, part of a mill development, but at one stage it was used as a schoolhouse, he said.ldquoIt sat as an empty shell for about six years. Since  it has been redeveloped and sympathetically extended by local builder Trevor Nelson, but I would say itrsquos only really finished now,itrsquos ever finished.When Richard and his mother, both of whom are originally from Crossgar, bought the house, it came along with birds nests and the usual natural build-up that empty houses accrue over the years.They could see the potential of the Coach Horse Lane home in a mill development with views of the local rolling hills and have been delighted with it ever since.ldquoItrsquos all open plan upstairs and has all of the original window ledges with open granite stonework and open beams with a sunroom and a large living room, said Richard.While he has been more focused on the interior of the house, the garden has been his motherrsquos domain.However, the homersquos interior reflects both their love of quirky and edgy looks and furnishings.ldquoIt was quite tricky to get the balance right. As itrsquos quite an old building, I did not want to go down the route of the old clicheacute of pitch pine and the Laura Ashley look, said Richard. ldquoItrsquos a real mixture as there is some very modern furniture which is married together with antiques. You have to be very exacting. It may not be everyonersquos cup of tea but the basis is traditional with very modern elements.Richard did not seek out entry to the competition rather the producers came to him.He said: ldquoI was approached by the programme makers through Instagram which is a surprise as even though Irsquom an interior designer, I donrsquot toot too much about my own house.ldquoNormally they would have come out to see the house before it was selected but because of Covid I had to give them a video tour of the house and they said they would be delighted to feature it.Neither Richard nor his mother were allowed to be at home when the three judges called to view the house lastSeptember, but he revealed the filming took two days in total.ldquoThe judges never meet the home owners as the house should speak for itself, he said.ldquoIt was a real experience as therersquos a lot of prep that goes into it. Therersquos a lot of disclaimers and I wasnrsquot allowed to talk about it until the week before. It involved the support and help from my neighbours who have been absolutely lovely.He added that his Basset dog, Walter, stole the show and has ended up appearing in the programmersquos opening credits every week.For further information, visit Richardrsquos website, www.rodrickdesign..prettyPhoto

title: Strangford buzzing as film crew rolls in
story: TELEVISION cameras rolled into Strangford last week.The village was buzzing recently when a TV advert production company visited a well-loved local hostelry.The recently refurbished Cuan bar and restaurant, is to star in new Tourism NI advert encouraging people to explore the region for staycations this year.The Cuanrsquos customer experience and Business development manager, Michael Dune, said the visit was very welcome.ldquoThe village was definitely buzzing with a film crew and it was great to be chosen to help represent the local area in what is likely to be a new TV advert, he said.ldquoThe attention was certainly very welcome as The Cuan changed hands last year but we havenrsquot been able to open since so the owner decided to do a major refurbishment which is almost complete. We are looking forward to re-opening again.He added that the restaurant and bar had all been extensively refurbished along with nine guest ensuite bedrooms including new bathrooms, furniture and deacutecor with styling by local interior designer Suzanne Garuda..prettyPhoto

title: The mood of the people is to get back to church
story: CHURCH leaders in Downpatrick have welcomed the imminent reopening of churches after lockdown.All churches have been closed to public worship since the New Year, but they will be open again in time for Easter.Catholic churches will reopen this Friday, while Protestant churches can reopen from Good Friday.Fr John Murray, parish priest of Downpatrick, said he was ldquototally behind the reopening, though he stressed that Covid- measures would be in place.St Patrickrsquos Church, which normally seats  people, will have its capacity reduced to  as a result of social distancing measures. The three other churches in the Downpatrick parish mdash St Colmcillersquos, St Brigidrsquos and St Malachyrsquos, Ballykilbeg mdash will remain closed.ldquoThe mood of the people is to get back to church, Fr Murray said. ldquoThe pandemic has been mentally punishing and one of the ways of helping people to cope is to go to mass and meet people.ldquoOur last public services were on Christmas Day and itrsquos been dficult for many people, although we have been blessed with a good webcam system and live streaming at St Patrickrsquos. People have definitely been watching the services and I know itrsquos a comfort that they have been able to worship in some form.He added: ldquoThere was a palpable sense of joy when we were reopened following the end of the first lockdown last July. I think it will be the same this Friday.The Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull, said the past three months had been a ldquostrange experience, but pointed out that the work of the church had continued, even though there was no public worship.Dean Hull leads a team of clergy responsible for Down Cathedral and  Church of Ireland churches in the Lecale area. He said almost all of them would be reopening for Easter.ldquoEaster is central to the Christian faith. It is a time of resurrection and hope. This year we also look forward to an end to the Covid pandemic and ato some form of normality, he remarked.Dean Hull said that although social distancing measures would be in place he hoped that people would enjoy the experience of going back to church.The Rev Owen Patterson, minister of Downpatrick and Ardglass Presbyterian Churches, described the reopening as the ldquostart of the road back to normality.He said he appreciated that some people might feel nervous about going back to church, though he hoped that the success of the vaccination programme would act as an encouragement.Mr Patterson said he was looking forward to services in both of his churches on Easter Sunday and pointed out that services would continue to be streamed online.The Rev Mervyn Ewing, minister of Donard Methodist Church, which covers Downpatrick, Dundrum and Newcastle, said he was looking forward to public worship resuming on Easter Sunday.ldquoThe church is about community and relationships. Those are things which we have missed dreadfully, he said. ldquoWe are looking forward to making contacting with one another physically and not just on a screen.Mr Ewing said the last three months had been ldquochallenging, though he emphasised that the church had continued to operate through prayer and pastoral support.He added: ldquoWe really hope that there will be no further lockdowns.The Rev Dr David Steers, minister of Downpatrick, Ballee and Clough Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Churches, welcomed ato church services, but stressed that safety was still the priority.Dr Steers said there would be services in all three churches on Easter Sunday.ldquoIt will be great to get back and worship together. One of the first things we did after the lockdown was to move things online, but itrsquos not the same as being able to see each other, he remarked.ldquoWe have tried to keep things going as best we can, but there are limitations to what you can do, such as with hospital visits. We are grateful to be ing to church..prettyPhoto

title: Travel capacity increase plans for schoolchildren
story: ADDITIONAL bus capacity for local post-primary students who ed to school on Monday has been promised by the Department of Education.The issue was raised by Portaferry councillor Joe Boyle who last week wrote to the Education Minister Peter Weir pressing for additional transport for students when all schoolsfor normal education.Students from Years - ed to school on Monday, along with all primary school children. Students from Years - are expected toto school after the Easter break on April .Cllr OrsquoBoyle said there were normally over  children using the ferry each day.ldquoWhilst the Department for Infrastructure is applying current government guidelines on the approximate seven-minute crossing on the Strangford Ferry Service, we cannot sit back and watch our students being packed to capacity on the current provision of transport with up to  passengers on each bus, urged the councillor.ldquoThe Education Authority, along with the Department of Education, are responsible for the transportation of all students and therefore this is a factor that needs to be addressed whenever all students and places of education are once again fully ing.The councillor claimed that current transport being provided was ldquofilled to capacity and buses going from Strangford village to Downpatrick and Ballynahinch had no social distancing in place.He added: ldquoWe must continue to apply care consideration and caution as we all move forward to getting back to some level of normality and adequate transportation needs to be put in place.ldquoThere are local coach operators with a number of coaches and drivers at the ready, whose businesses have been signicantly impacted upon during the past year, and this would therefore be a win-win for both the Education Authority and those locally based coach operators.A Department of Education spokesperson said: ldquoAdditional capacity has been provided with the full school bus network due to resume on Monday, March , in line with the phasedof pupils. Translink has rigorous cleaning regimes in place alongside a range of other safety measures.ldquoAll post primary pupils are reminded it is mandatory to wear a face covering on all home to school transport both dedicated and public and it is also strongly encouraged that all pupils, regardless of age, should wear a face covering where it is appropriate for them to do so. Pupils are also reminded to follow wider safety travel advice including good hand hygiene, socially distance and use pre-paid tickets such as mLink or travelcards where they are not eligible for a sessional school pass.The spokesman said that the range of additional services that were put in place was sufficient to ensure the implementation of the current guidance.ldquoHowever, the department and the EA will continue to be guided by the relevant public health advice to ensure that transport is safe as possible for pupils.The spokesperson added that mitigating measures such as driver cough screens, hand sanitiser on all EA vehicles had been put in place, along with frequent bus cleaning.It was also recommended that pupils should seek a safe social distance from one and other and sit in their relevant year groups where possible..prettyPhoto

title: Ulster National takes place behind closed doors again
story: FOR the second season in succession, Downpatrickrsquos most important race of the year was run behind closed doors.Even so, a lot of fans took the opportunity to enjoy the racing that is the natural grandstand of Jim Crows Hill along the Vianstown Road.The Randox Ulster National, the richest and also the longest race at Downpatrick at three milesand four furlongs, saw the maximum  runners go to post.Victory went to Fae An Bealach, trained in Co Meath by Tony Martin and ridden by the excellent Darragh OrsquoKeefe, who put in a good finish to fend off two local hopes in Flinch, trained at Crossgar by Colin McBratney, and third-placed Askann, trained by Mervyn Torrens for his we, Anne. Torrens previously won the race back in  with Hughies Grey. SP:  ,  ,  .The first three home in the Boardsmill Sires Maiden Hunters Chase were locally owned and trained, and two of them had local riders.First past the judge was Big Leg Up in the colours of Moira vet Ian Moore. Pulled up in his two most recent point-to-points, the   shot provided a first winning ride for Simon Cavanagh.Winning trainer Gerry Cosgrave, from Katesbridge, saddled Honeysuckle to win her first race at a point to point. The mare, which won the Champion Hurdle at Cheltenham last week, is unbeaten in  runs under rules.In a good battle for second the grey Dento Des Obeaux, ridden by Noel McParlan for Downpatrick businessman Liam Gibney, held off Tareeshar, owned by Loughinislandrsquos Paddy Madine and ridden by Deckie Lavery. Both horses are trained by Downpatrickrsquos Paddy Turley, who is based in the centre of the racecourse.The third race on the card, WKD Handicap Chase, was won by Springfield Lodge, ridden by Cheltenham winning jockey Jordan Gainford who made the trip from Cork worth it for trainer Eoghan OrsquoGrady.Mullaghmurphy Blue, ridden by another Cheltenham winning jockey in Keith Donoghue, was second with Crack on Corrie in third. SP:  ,  ,  .This victory provided recently turned professional Gainford his first career double after winning the dayrsquos opening race, the Connollys Red Mills Irish EBF Auction Maiden Hurdle, with   favourite Stranger Danger.In second place was Gelee Blanche, ridden by champion jockey Paul Townend, who made the running until the final flight. Sam Lorenzo, ridden by Neil Gault for his uncle, Ballyclare-based Billy Bryson, kept on well to finish third. SP:   fav,  ,  .The winner is trained in Co Meath by Denise lsquoSneezyrsquo Foster who is now in charge at the stables of Gordon Ellliot, the champion trainer at Downpatrick in recent years.In the Randox Rated Hurdle, Pure Genius, trained by Ted Walsh, made every post a winning one in the well known green and gold hooped colours of JP McManus. Ridden by his retained Irish-based jockey Mark Walsh, the easy winner was followed home by Bold Enough and Mitehouka.The WKD Handicap Hurdle Race was won by   outsider My Manekineko, owned and trained by former top amateur James Nash at the Curragh. The gelding was ridden by lb claimer Michael OrsquoConnor.Justbecool, ridden by Paddy Kennedy, took second and in third was Lilys gem, owned and trained in Larne by Stuart Crawford and ridden by his brother, Ben.The concluding race on the card was the Molson Coorsflat race and the always placed   shot Drumbear took first place ahead of Deckie Lavery on Tempo Chapter Two. Game And Glory, ridden by Patrick Mullins for Lisburn owner John Leckey, finished third.Winning jockey Ben Harvey has taken a liking to the track after he rode Space Cadet to win last yearrsquos Ulster National..prettyPhoto
